reviewText:
I have this game. I LOVE this game.

However, I cannot rate this positive at all.

UPlay may be a joke, but it is a sufferable joke. The real problem is much scarier than that.

----------
SolidShield.
----------

What is SolidShield?

SolidShield is a software DRM engine that was built for corporate applications, NOT computer games. In the business world, people only upgrade computers once every few years. By the time they upgrade a couple of times, the software is obsolete and has been superseded by a later version.

Many gamers are completely different. A lot of us format our machines at least once a year, sometimes more often than that. A lot of us change our hardware semi-regularly as well, particularly video cards, hard disk drives and memory.

This is a huge problem, you see, because all of these changes change the hardware fingerprint that SolidShield uses to 'protect' its software payload. It's akin to the Windows activation system with the very major difference that it it is extremely hyperactive, and very intrusive.

According to Ubisoft, who has said in the past that the PC gaming market is terrible, we are never allowed to change our hardware configurations. If we do, we are obligated to buy a new copy.

Ubisoft says piracy has caused them to require this ridiculous DRM system, which isn't suitable for games at all.

I counter that the existence of SolidShield in this product is causing people to prefer pirating this game to buying it. After all, if you pirate it, you'll actually be able to install it when you feel like playing it in two years' time.

I've never before seen a company that shows such a disdain for its customers. If it were up to me, I'd remove ALL DRM from Anno 2070, and give it away for free (or a lot less than its $60 price tag) as an apology to all of us for having to put up with this travesty.

Until TAGES SolidShield is COMPLETELY REMOVED from this product, I cannot see how anyone could possibly rate it positively.

reviewText:
DON'T. BUY. THIS.
Every time I see this game on sale, I'm painfully reminded of the 12€ I wasted on this and I don't want you to feel the same.
If the goddess of fortune smiled upon you so you actually managed to go through one hour min of installing all the content through Ubisoft's trainwreck of a software, you will still have to pray for her mercy so that the servers are up because if they're not, you won't be playing the game.
But amazingly it's not the game's worst offense, because on top of that it has the ♥♥♥♥♥iest kind of DRM: you can only install the game thrice, and after that, you have to contact Ubisoft's customer service to get another key to play a videogame you already paid for.
I know the game looks beautiful, it actually is the most city builder I've played, but don't fall for this venus flytrap. Avoid this game on the store like it's the black plague. Pirate it instead and spare yourself the 10€ it costs on sale because otherwise you won't get to play it ever.
I couldn't save myself back then but at least I can warn you.

reviewText:
FIXING UPLAY:

UPVOTE THIS SO EVERYONE KNOWS

The reason Uplay crashes when you try to launch from Steam is because Uplay does not install properly when the install is queued/prompted by Steam itself.

INSTEAD, download and install the standalone Uplay launcher.

THEN, run the new standalone Uplay install and log in with your account.

NOW, you can launch the game from steam as usual as long as Uplay is running and you are logged in.

reviewText:
This is where the Anno series take a dive, and it's all Ubisoft's own fault.

Let me repeat these:

1) No game should ever force you into having an active internet connection when playing a singleplayer game.

2) And no singleplayer game should ever require an active internet connection in order to use in game items.

3) And no game with active connection requirement should ever wipe your progress clean when you are accidentally offline, without any remediation.

Ubisoft managed to ruin Anno 2070 by making all 3 mistakes. Sorry, couple these with a UI interface that alienate big screen, I just can't go on.

reviewText:
Before I get into the utter disgrace to the gaming industry that is Ubisoft, I have to say that the game itself is absolutely fantastic. Brilliant and immersive in both its gameplay and UI, studying the most practical and most efficient ways of marriage between trade and development in a world of a realistic near-future setting, really a great addition to the Anno franchise.

However, despite the game's overwhelmingly positive qualities, DO NOT buy this game through steam. The publisher, Ubisoft, especially Uplay, ♥♥♥♥ed it in the ♥♥♥ with a foot-long cactus and completely ruined the experience from the start. This is a fair warning, to spare you the details of nightmarish hours of technical difficulties with it being a non-steam based game trying to use another game distributing software, save your time and money and hope for Ubisoft's demise as everything they touch descends into oblivion. I can only pray for Anno 2205's fate as any franchise sharing a destiny with Ubisoft is doomed to collapse.

reviewText:
Good game, but Uplay is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off.

Actual Review:
Anno 2070 is an amazing resource management sim. Very fun to slowly develop your colony into a thriving city with supply lines and all.

However, that's all well and good but the game seriously is boring when it comes to combat, since only air/navel units are available. And even those are really limited to fight with. (2 aircraft, about 4 attack vessals)

The game is a really good concept, but for me after a few hours of gameplay I've maxed out my cities and all that's left is to fully eradicate my 'opponents'. Note opponents being barely true as everyone is just trying to survive.

Beautiful graphics however, alright OST. uPlay is absolutely horrid, most likely it will take you about an hour to get the game working if uPlay decides to deny you entry to the game you just paid for.

I can't recommend this as late game there really isn't anything to do, so many other issues also..

reviewText:
Anno 2070 is a very good game! When compared to older Anno games they've really taken some bold moves and they do work well. However, I am NOT RECOMMENDING this very GOOD GAME. Related designs (the developer) has done nothing wrong, Ubisoft (the publisher) does a lot of things wrong. I will tell you a bit about the game, but also WARN you about Ubisoft and their pushy ways. I wish someone told me before I bought this game, because I wouldn't have bought it! Please read along!

A few years ago I was playing CivCity Rome. Off course I had heard of Anno, but untill then I had never played it. Then I tried Anno 1404 and I was instantly sold. Anno is a citybuilding game that is always set in a specific era. Instead of needing power and water, your citizens would like to have food and goods that you need to create for them. You build your city (or cities) on a map consisting of a bunch of islands that each have their own resources which you will need to create the goods you people want. When their wishes have been met, they grow a level. This causes the house to grow and support more people but it also generates more taxes for each citizen living there. Anno always goes very deep, you have to manage the fleet of ships carrying the goods around, time them, have the right amounts in stock etc, and sometimes when I'm about 24hrs into one sandbox game, it starts to feel like a lot of work! You must keep the production going, sell excess goods, don't go bankrupt, build that monument, manage trade routs,,,

Anno comes in many flavors, just pick your favorite age and go! The latest installments are the most consistently playing ones, and with this new Anno 2070 they really made the game a lot more accessible to new players and old players alike, when it comes to the amounts of resources in a map for instance. I have a few minor points of critisism about some of the made choices though. And for me, the futuristic theme is ok, but the style is a bit bland for my taste. For instance, in Anno 1404 the palet of colors was more vibrant on my led-tv for instance. I also like seeing dozens and dozens of wooden sail ships being processed at a big massive harbor, rectangular electric ships just aren't the same. When it comes to graphics in general, this Anno is really good looking with the later effects though. I still prefer 1404, but it's a matter of taste. The action (yes, there is also warfare, limited islands and resources mean war! sometimes) is still not really spectacular and really... I don't like it. I like the building and trading! I have not played this Anno a lot or a long time, but it plays familiar enough to judge that it is a good Anno. Related Design does not screw up their beloved Anno I think! Anno games are generally good, this one is no exception... however I personally still prefer Anno 1404, it also comes without Uplay, the reason I'm not recommending this game!

I would score the game 8/10 if it weren't for the game's publisher Ubisoft. I would really like to warn you about them! Really annoying buggers they are!

Usually here on Steam, when you buy a game it downloads and you can play it. No worries, no fuss. Sometimes there is some online DRM, annoying and pointless but ok... Sometimes it's an online game, understandable that they want you to create a seperate account with them.

But then comes along Ubisoft and their pushy Uplay services". I know one thing

reviewText:
Beautiful and fun game for this type of genre. Very well done interface outside of actual game as well- with the factions, faction reputation, events, global voting events to 'elect' officials that boost different stats every week or so. I was, and still am, very impressed with this emmersion.

Unfortunatley, its really no longer maintained well by Ubisoft. World events are, as of this posting, no longer going on (and you pay for these as part of game and DLC). Tremendous problems with their third party DRM ( in the multiple years I've owned this I have had no less than 5 issues that were gamebreaking and had to be resolved and hindered playability). In addition, since updated Uplay workings (around Sept 2015) I have had problems saving the game. It was working fine and then this happened - not sure 100% if it a causation effect or just a correlation. This is not a game where you finish too many levels in one sitting hence it has made the game all but unplayable for me!

As a game - I highly reccommend it. I very much enjoyed so many aspects. However...
The condition of the game, and how it simply just doesnt work well these days - I would not reccommend you buying.
Hope this helps a bit in your choice to buy or not!

reviewText:
Anno 2070 is a very relaxing, and an incredibly in depth RTS. I call it an RTS, but it is an economy focused RTS, and can be played entirely without any combat or war what so ever.

The focus of the game is on building your society up and seeing to your peoples needs.

The single player features a story driven campaign which serves as a good starting point to learning the basics of game play. There is quite a steep learning curve to this game, but luckily there are a lot of resources online to aid new players. Also there are some really in depth guides hear on Steam that can help out in a variety of areas. Don't be put off by the massive amount of information involved in this game, you can learn how things work, and why you do it is very satisfying.

Graphically Anno 2070 is demanding, and you'll want a high end card to get the best out of the graphics. But it looks great, for sure one of the better looking stratagy games out there.

This game is probably more like a city building game with a strong emphasis on economy, and supply chains. So if your into that, you'll really enjoy this.

The pace of the game can be slow a steady. If your looking to build up and make everything work, you need to take your time. So the game, once you get the hang of it, is very relaxing.

If you have any interest in this sort of thing at all, you should pick it up. And hey the developers even removed the always online DRM, so you can play offline :3 SUCK IT sim city!

reviewText:
TLDR - I find this game both relaxing and challenging. Take UPlay out of the picture and this game comes highly recommended!

It saddens me that there are so many negative reviews for this wonderful game, and all of them are due to the draconian implementation of Uplay. I've been lucky enough to not have any problems with Uplay or the DRM, so I will speak only to the game itself.

In the new, wet future, you are charged with rebuilding society and wrestling the dwindling resources from what is left of the waterlogged planet. Maps consist of several islands, both above and below water. Your goal is settle a colony and grow it accordingly to meet your citizens needs to work your way up to the tech level needed to satisfy the mission objectives. You start each map with a single ship, and enough supplies to get your first colony going. There are 2 major factions: ecos" and industrialists
hoursPlayed: are available to both. You can also start building with the opposite factions buildings after you have reached a certain level of citizens. Each faction has several tiers of development
voteText: with the highest tiers requiring an insane amount of scarce resources/factory combines to get the finished products needed to satisfy demand.\n\nEach map has different objectives
helpfulPercent: and you are given a lot of freedom in how you want to meet your goals. Do I want to spam out a lot of low end housing and industries
votesHelpful: or work my way up the chain to produce more lucrative products? Either approach
votesTotal: or a combination of the two works - but your citizens get increasingly needy and harder to please the further up the tech trees you go. Random disasters and events (some scripted) also crop up to keep things interesting.\n\nIt's pretty easy to stay on top of things and zip through some of the earlier missions
votesFunny: where you only need to deal with a few different resources and citizens needs. The later missions
commentsCount: and especially the expansion ones
column16: will have you scrambling for dozens of hours to keep up with your multi-island society of thousands of citizens. It is incredibly rewarding to finally beat one of these after whittling away at it for close to a week!\n\nImportant to note: There is some combat
column17: but the focus here is supply & demand
column18: logistics
column19: and keeping your balance out of the red. If you like RTS games
column21: you probably will not have a good time here.\n\nOne thing I really like with this game

column25: and the many different types of alerts warn you when something major needs your attention. Systems are there to automate trading
column26: both at each island depot themselves
column27: and trade routes with ships. There are tons of technologies to research

reviewText:
Anno 2070 offers the perfect synergy of RTS, City Building and Trading. I recommend the complete edition because the Deep Sea expansion adds a layer of extra depth to the tech trees.

In Anno 2070, the size of your city is limited only by the size of your island--and there are some really BIG islands. If for some reason you aren't satisfied with your island, build some nukes, launch them, watch the pretty mushroom clouds and then move into your newly acquired glass parking lot (island). Don't feel like remediating nuclear radiation from your newly conquered paradise? Try sabotaging your enemies' main food source--destroy an oil tanker off the coast of an enemy island (preferably next to their fish hatcheries) and while he/she scrambles to clean up the oil, harass the cleanup crew with fast attack boats or helicopters and then send in your attack fleet. Even better, with the Deep Sea expansion, you can create tsunamis to wipe out your enemies' coastal holdings by destroying strategically placed geothermal power plants. After all, your citizens are worth more than your enemies' citizens, especially if your enemy happens to be the Eden faction... those hippie tree-hugging ♥♥♥♥s! Pick the Tycoons and use the power of coal and nuclear energy to crush the little Eco ♥♥♥♥♥! There's no Captain Planet to help them against your rain of nuclear fire! Crush them and their tree covered islands and pave over everything with concrete!

Anno 2070 is not your typical city builder. As I explained earlier, this game is more of a hybrid City Builder, RTS and Trade Sim. Unlike traditional city builders, Anno 2070 has warfare. If warfare isn't your thing, you can play a peaceful game or you can eliminate your enemies through economic policy (hostile takeover). A hostile takeover is not as intricate as it sounds because all it involves is buying out enemy island shares until you have greater than 50% but, it adds another unique aspect to Anno 2070 game-play.

Another feature that sets Anno 2070 apart from other city builders is that you, the player, have 100% control over everything that is constructed. Compared to traditional city builders where the AI constructs buildings after the player zones an area for residential/commercial/industrial--Anno 2070 gives the player COMPLETE control over all structures: construction, destruction and placement. This is the perfect feature of the anal-retentive City-Building fanatic because it allows the control freak to CONTROL!

Placing buildings in Anno 2070 is almost like playing a puzzle game. Its always good to maximize space so when you're building in Anno 2070, be prepared to destroy and rebuild. I have over 200 hours in my current continuous game and I've rebuilt each of my major cities 3 times. I also razed and rebuilt the entire power grid across all 29 of my islands (largest map size). The reason for the rebuilding is pretty simple--I keep thinking of better and more efficient ways build, produce goods and house my citizens. My 3 largest cities started with max populations of: 29,000, 29,500 and 34,000 and each of them barely had enough power to keep on the lights. Now, those same islands boast populations of 34,500, 37,500 and 40,500 and each island has 1000+ excess power to share with the power grid.

Honestly, this game is a blast! The only reason Anno 2070 doesn't have 'Overwhelmingly Positive' reviews is because people hate on the Uplay DRM. I agree that its annoying but, its no reason to avoid one of the best city builder/rts hybrids of all-time.

EDIT: I noticed a number of people complaining that Uplay doesn't work for Anno 2070. Since I hadn't played in a few weeks I decided to boot it up and see if there was a problem. Uplay works just fine. The Steam version of Uplay is outdated. You need to update Uplay and everything works just fine.

The fix for this is so simple its mind boggling how many people fail to see it when its mentioned in numerous threads within the community hub. I know the Steam fan-boy knee-jerk reaction is to hate/blame any third party DRM so I guess I shouldn't be so surprised.

EDIT 10/17/2015: I see the reviews for this game keep slipping BUT not because the game-play is bad. The reviews are slipping because a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥-♥♥♥ Steam fan-boys hate Uplay DRM. Sorry boys but, Uplay works just fine and has done ZERO to inhibit my Anno 2070 gaming experience.

reviewText:
It seems that most people not recommending this game are actually doing so on the basis of its 4th Party DRM; while archaic and utterly infuriating, being that Steam is already 3rd Party DRM, it does not reflect on the game itself.

Anno 2070 is a beautiful open world city-building game with many different strategy aspects intertwined. Think of it like a far more advanced, far more stable, version of Sim City, with missions, singleplayer, NPCs, combat, and trading. Not to mention underwater city building.

You can choose from 2 factions in game - An ecologist faction and a trade faction, each one with its advantages and disadvantages. As the environment plays a fairly key role in the game, your decisions as to how your islands develop and the pollution they produce can seriously affect end-game production, as more and more buildings are required to cope with the diminished returns of crops and livestock. However, pollution is necessary for supplies and income to be produced en masse; you, the player, must decide on how you choose to build up your city(s)

Anno 2070's soundtrack is nice, without being too overbearing; it's certainly more mellow than other games, but for good reason. It's a nice listen, and I never play the game with music set to off.

The game's graphics still look beautiful, even for a game that is 2 years old. The lighting and shadow effects are phenomenal, with water rendering that doesn't much detract from my FPS. What isn't shown in the screenshots is the underwater portions of the game, in that you can build supply depots and other research facilities under the sea. I strongly suggest if you're interested in that sort of thing you look up a video on it, it's rather amazing.

Overall, the game is fun, very fun, enough to warrant a solid 8.5/10 from me; its seemingly laidback start to any game belies a hidden undertone of complexity not seen in most city building games such as this one.

I have yet to play the game, but I'd like to warn people about the absolutely horrific way this is setup.
Install the game. Enter 'CD-key'.
Install Uplay. Enter 'CD-key'
Close Uplay.
Start the game (you think)
Combine steam with uplay account.
Restart Uplay.
Start the game.
Combine Uplay with game and ofc enter 'CD-key'.

reviewText:
Uplay is no-play

This sums up my review in a nut-shell. No matter how great this game may be, it does not justify the hassles and potential problems one may find in using Uplay.

Took me 6 hrs to download the game from steam only to get an estimate of 21 hrs + through Uplay. Though it should be noted steam was downloading only 3 Gigs and Uplay 4.5 Gigs, a shocking difference I know. I would assume this is due to the limited sources Uplay comes from for as I monitor my network activity, steam is maintaining many more connections and images from DIFFERENT LOCATIONS.

Uplay is annoying as hell and doesn't belong on steam. Steam SHOULD be thouroughly warning its customers when they need to go through a steam-knock-off server/client. To avoid doing so is a direct conflict of customer satisfaction.

reviewText: I've played all previous Anno games and I've loved them all. It is a great game to relax at due to its slow nature. You can even turn off military actions within your skirmish game so you can focus on building up your city and anything you want. You can take as many islands as you wish and build a city and production on every one of them. Eventually you can get to build underwater production which is an exciting addition to the game and a wonderful idea. Even after multiple hours of game time you can't actually finish building everything because there is simply so much to do and build. An other great improvement is the graphics that looks stunning and therefore screenshots and videos from it are beautiful.

I only have 3 words to say :

Don't Buy It.

Now, here is the reason why :

I will not extend myself on the game, as it is probably nicier and more fun than I could even imagine. And it pain me that I could not play it.

BUT to play this game you have to install UPLAY and bend over to what ever decision Ubisoft make. And don't get me wrong. I don't mind a 'nicely done DRM that treat the customer right'. But I don't support DRM done wrong that consider every single buyer to be 'potential pirate'.

The fact that Ubisoft want every of their players connected constantly is only the proof they are completely out of their mind. They have imposed real bad DRM over the years (the destructive Starforce for example) and they have pushed the whole system over the edge.

Mixing a limit of 3 activation for a game, with the need to be constantly online is just.... how to say.... feeling like I need to pee in the check tube every time I connect to my computer and have the police of the town authorizing me to move around with an electronic bracer and a tailing car.

reviewText:
Sad sad Ubisoft.

Don't get me wrong, this is a beautiful, extensive, and immersive game. It is an above ground and underwater city builder with complex city management and trade.  HOWEVER, UPlay is a horrendous gaming network and a DRM of 3 installs is appalling (to say it kindly). When I discovered I could only install this on 3 machines I was quite disappointed.

Ubisoft support also seems seriously lacking. My son recently made purchase of a hardcopy ubisoft title, registered it to his account but could not download it - was just stuck in a registration loop. He was outright ignored by Ubisoft/Uplay official support contact - even after posting for help on their Facebook page. Eventually he exchanged the game for something worth twice as much (and not needing Uplay). So he posted again to their facebook to let them know he didnt want their assistance anymore because they are useless and he had solved his problem. Within minutes they deleted his post from the page making us well aware that Uplay had seen his original help request but they had deliberately ignored it.

I'd hate to see what will happen when I have to contact them for a new key for Anno when I next upgrade my machine. If the same DRM restrictions exist for the new Anno when it is released I simply wont be buying it ... ever. In fact my experience with the few Uplay games I do own has taught me to be extremely wary of investing in any Ubisoft games again.

reviewText: Anno 2070 is a complex game it takes a RTS (real time strategy) to a new level.  But if you love building cities, having limited resources, and limited land this game is for you.  Took me more then a few restarts to get a feel for this game but its so beautiful when it all comes together.  Its all about making do with what your granted and balancing it with the environment, and keeping your citizens happy with supply and demand so they can improve so you can improve.   Also lets not forget about the trade because that island next you more then likely has something you want be it rice, sugar, oil you get the idea.  This game is a must for any true die hard RTS gamer or even the casual RTS gamer but don't get your panties in a bunch cause you fail.  You need patience and understanding and the willingness to scrap your game and start over to achieve greatness in this game.

reviewText:
This game reminds me of Caeser, Pharoah, and the other economy-based city-builders of the 90's and early 2000's. I haven't played any other Anno games so I cannot comment on if this is a good or bad Anno game, but I've really enjoyed it. You have to build a city while managing a bunch of different resources, which are used to upgrade your city and advance up the technology chain. You can only get certain resources from some islands, so you need to either expand your empire or trade with other players. It's a little complex, and it can get very overwhelming in the late game when you are dealing with many islands and every resource, but it's really satisftying when everything clicks into place and you have a functioning chain of islands.

The big downside is the Uplay DRM. It's actually problem-free for me, but I can't deny that it is utterly useless. It runs in the background for no real reason, and you need to sign up for a Uplay account. If you're lucky like I am, that's all the  interaction you'll need to do with Uplay. I know some people have an avalanche of problems, so your mileage may vary.

Get the Deep Sea expansion, because it adds a whole new faction to the game and it feels incomplete without it.

I'm not sure if the campaign really goes anywhere, and the bulk of the game seems to be based around the sandbox-esque continuous game mode. So, if you're looking for goals and missions, you might want to look elsewhere. If you like managing cities and supply lines, and micromanagement is your game, you'll probably have a great time here.

Before buying this game you have to know, that it is supported by UPlay, so before getting oportunity to play this game will take you about an hour to:

- install the updates

- insert your new login and pass for Uplay

After that game starts. You think that is all? No! After you log in the game you have to:

- download more updates of the game
- reboot the game
- more some kind of updates


After that they will make a proposition on a large banner for you to play Anno Online (even they have to understand you are playing it the first time).

After all this crap, when I finally could be able to play, I just log out this ***** game. And I think my next experience with it will be not very soon, I better play with more easer games to install and get opportunity to play.

reviewText:
This is not a bad game if you can manage to launch it.
When you install the game, do not launch it. If you do, uPlay will crash on start. Go to the uPlay site and create an account if you don't already have one. Add the game to your account from the uPlay web site. Download the uPlay launcher from the web site and install it on top of the one included in the Steam version. If you don't follow these steps, uPlay will repeatedly crash and you won't be able to play at all.
The single player missions are tough and actually require strategy and a grasp of the economy. You will run out of money and you will try many different strategies to scrape together the cash you need to continue. This is essentially a city builder with a great deal of micromanagement, not a war game.
As you progress, game elements and enhancements can be unlocked with points earned. An internal voting system exists for everyone playing through uPlay to elect factions which provide various buffs. Unfortunately, uPlay's internal achievements and points system don't allow for Steam cards or achievements.
If you can get past the extremely frustrating nuisance that is uPlay and manage the steep learning curve, you will enjoy the game.

reviewText:
Both the game as an entertainment piece and as a product should be reviewed and considered when deciding whether or not to give money to the people who made it.

In this case, they will treat you like you are a thief by default with a broken 3rd party DRM. You can end up locked out of your game and having to go through to a customer support nightmare to prove you own this legitimately. Surprisingly, this is a problem a pirate will never have. Which begs the question: why did they put this DRM in the first place?

The game is all right, but as with much of what they publish, not worth having to deal with Ubisoft.

Overzealous publishers need to either remove their games from Steam to avoid two pieces of DRM conflicting or to remove theirs and trust Steam (which is light years ahead in my opinion).

If you're really keen on this game I'd suggest getting it directly on Uplay or elsewhere.

reviewText:
Anno 2070 is a hybrid resource management, city building sim and RTS by Ubisoft. Using futuristic technology, you must build a city to complete various goals while balancing the favor of three factions.

The main campaign for Anno 2070 revolves around a rogue A.I. and the steps that you must take to protect your people while solving the puzzle of how to defeat it. The story is told through in game events as you complete quests, and through pre and post mission cutscenes. While story can be somewhat secondary in these types of games, I found it rather compelling and was definitely interested in what would happen next.

For the campaign mode, you will be designing your city so that you can complete certain goals given to you by one of three factions, which are representative of business, technology and environment. Towards later missions you will be balancing the needs of multiple factions, whose unique buildings or abilities you will need to complete your quests. Since your city is persistent through multiple levels, this can create some issues while you are planning. You may spend one whole mission optimizing your city for the tech faction, only to find out later that you will need high level buildings from the business faction to continue. Your cities are mostly built on islands, and square footage is at a premium, so this can be problematic. Luckily for the most part there is not much of a penalty for having to tear down a building to place something new in its place, but still you can find yourself having spent hours designing a city perfectly just to find out later you have to tear it down.

Game balance is done very well. You will need to provide your citizens with certain goods, depending on what faction they are from, and most of these goods can be manufactured in your buildings. You will need to balance your cash, power supply and ecobalance to complete each mission, and luckily there are generally ways to increase each if you are patient.

Graphics are top notch, as our sound effects and voice acting. A lot of effort was put into the creation of this game, and it shows.

After completing the main storyline, there is still plenty to accomplish. There are council votes which you can participate in, and will give you bonuses to certain factions. There are many scenarios to play through. The main story can take you upwards of 20 hours or more to complete, and if you still want more to do, more is available.

Overall, I would completely recommend Anno 2070. It has that one more turn mentality that can keep you hooked for hours at a time. There is so much to do even after the main campaign that you will definitely get your money's worth. Anno 2070 is highly polished, well balanced, and very, very entertaining.

Score: A-

reviewText: Beautiful, Smooth, and Enjoyable. Unlike other strategy games like Civilization, Meridian: New World, Starcraft, etc, this game focues on more realistic ideals. Economy, Citizens, Resources, and the Environment are the main aspects. Now you may say that this game sounds like any other, but it focuses on these aspects greatly. You can't just build a mine on a resource and expect it to instantly be accessible and have the resource flowing to your city. Time el facto is one thing, it takes time for resources to go from point a to point b. Citizens have needs and there are different demographics for citizens. They level up as you fulfill there desires earning you more technology and resources. The economy is based on your tax income and expenses. Unit maintenance, citizen's needs, tax rates, and trade all affect tax income. The important part is the environment. Disasters, cities, units, and resources are affected by how polluted or clean the environment is. Great game, Co-op is good, everything is good.

reviewText: I purchased this game in 2011. I have never been able to launch it (I can get into the main menu). I have tried numerous times in five years. Ubisoft DRM stops me everytime. You can see I have 3.5 hours of time in-game. That's time spent attempting to connect to Ubisoft's servers, and also time the game (at the main menu) has been minimized while I've been troubleshooting. Nothing. Numerous support tickets over the years have not even yielded a single response. I have one open now that's been unanswered for a few hours shy of a week. Worse, I am not an exception to these issues. 62% of ~7000 reviews are positive, and quickly scanning the negative reviews shows that a large number of paying customers share this problem. That's at least 2500 customers that Ubisoft has basically written off over the years, and it doesn't even include the customers who don't own the game on Steam or haven't given it a thumbs up/thumbs down. That's bad. I wouldn't chance this if I were you.\n\nEdit: For anyone that's curious, after ten days I finally received a response from Ubisoft support. I was told I need to activate the game on Steam. In fairness, I'm not sure I made it perfectly clear in the support ticket that the game is installed on Steam, so I messaged them back. We'll see where it goes. It is worth noting I think the ticket classification which is essentially key is already in use" corresponds with an error message you get in-game that tells you all the same. reviewText:
I don't know how to review Anno 2070.  The game isn't for everyone.  It's a complex logistics chain simulator, in essence.  The game focuses very little on 'city-building', in actuality.  The primary focus that consumes the game is production chain management.  You have limited space, and multiple islands, and you have to get raw resource A polished into finished good B, and then get B delivered to the particular population that is demanding the good.

The game has many other elements, including building cities.   It has a lot of beautification and aesthetic items you can add.  It's the best of the Anno series I've played thus far.

Essentially, if you like making a well-oiled machine and watching the beautiful results of said machine, you'll like this game.  If you don't like managing supply chains and trade routes, you won't like this game.

I adore this game.

reviewText:
I don't usually like to write reviews. When I write them, its hard to put my thoughts into words because my understanding of a game is almost always different than another person's understanding. Nonetheless, I need to write a review for Anno 2070 because i've spent enough time with this game to put my thoughts into words. TL;DR is at the bottom if you want it.

I'll start with what most people consider the deal-breaker with Anno 2070, which is Ubisoft and their toadies Blue Byte and Related Design. Ubisoft, in their *infinite* knowledge, decided to shoehorn in their UPlay DRM for what seems to be no reason. In fact, all it does is break the game for some and make another hoop to jump through for others. Either way, its annoying. But reviews on Steam aren't gonna stop them, so I won't drag on about them.

But I will drag on about Blue Byte and Related Design. If these guys weren't owned by Ubisoft, I can make a safe bet that if these guys were runned by a more consumer-friendly company, than we wouldn't see issues like losing integral parts of the game overtime or having to jump through hoops to get the game running. But the problem is that these developers are too afraid of telling Ubisoft to shove-it, so we end up with all these issues in their games. I know that both of these developers can produce very amazing games, but because they can't be self aware we end up with carcasses of games overtime.

Enough about the people, let's get to the game. It is basically the mammoth of the Anno 2070 franchise. More factions, more AI competitors, more goods, more everything! This was my first Anno game, and although it was a little overwhelming at first, I got the hang of it after a while. This game is luckily very well polished, and has been updated overtime to make a better experience. The soundtrack, graphics, and mechanics are all top notch. I couldn't have asked for anything more. I'm not gonna get into the gameplay, but once you look on YouTube or you play the campaign it'll become easy to get the hang of. I do want to warn you though that certain features are just plain different from when the older videos were made or when the campaign was made. As of writing this review for the game I am in the works of creating an updated tutorial/let's play for anyone who wants to get into this game now. That may be available at some point.

Let's just address some new things before I end this review. The DLC is certainly worth it, and expands the game so much you can't resist. It will make your life easier. However, the only DLC you may want is the Deep Ocean expansion. The rest is just little cosmetics or things that will be a minor benefactor in the end. As for the current state of the game, they removed the 'World Events' system, which is a little bit of a pain, but you'll probably still be okay. The best part of Anno 2070, in my opinion, is the experience building and nuturing a whole civilization. That won't ever be going away, so if you wish to share that experience, then this game is certainly for you.

TL;DR: Although Ubisoft and their Toadies are a pain, the actual game is a breath-taking experience that will be a staple of the city builder for a long time.

reviewText:
I'm starting this review off by saying that as a newcomer to the Anno series, I really enjoyed this game. The production chain building and shipping from island to island is well done and is quite fun. It also offers a surprising amount of replayability. Also unlike some other old Ubisoft titles (Endwar springs to mind) the serverside portion of the game (voting on events, timed missions, ect) is still running and offers a good shakeup. Its worth noting that I haven't tried the domination multiplayer gamemode, but it looks like it is very good.

I unfortunatly can't comment on the graphics because every computer I've run this game on is a potatoe, but thats my problem.

Onto what caused so many people to vote this game down, the DRM. I personally haven't had any trouble with it but I installed Uplay before hand because of other games, so I don't speak for the majority of the playerbase aparently.

The elephant in the room, Tages, almost never caused me problems and when it did it was understandable. The only time I ran into an issue was when I was messing about with VM's and I only ran into the problem on the 5th VM try. All it took to fix it was talking to ubisoft support to get it sorted out, and I haven't had a problem since.

All in all, near perfect game (the combat is very obviously not the focus of gameplay or design work) with a little bit of annoyance related to DRM, but nothing that even got me close to upset. I'd recomend this game at anything up to $45, as the amount of enjoyment you can get out of it is amazing.

reviewText:
I am glad that I decided not to listen to the mass of childish reviews regarding the annoyance of Uplay and the loading times.

I enjoy this game for the city building aspect set in a futuristic world.
The graphics are good, however don't expect to fall in love with them unless you zoom all the way in.
Controls and objectives were not clear initially, however after a few hours things make 'sense' for why the developers have made the game this way.

Overall if people haven't bought this simply because of the loading, and they have a mere few hours to their names, please disregard them. Keep it on your wish list, and purchase when it is on sale - but purchase you should if you enjoy sim building experiences.

reviewText: I was really impressed with my first impression... The single player campagin starts as the corporate tycoons exploiting the earths resources, you can see the beautiful environment slowly fade and erode into nothingness. An island that once was inhabited by deer and bears becomes barren and the beautiful seascape of whales and dolphins becomes empty... This is until the game introduces the environmentally friendly faction which attempts to establish a balance with nature, with a slower production rate, yet sustainable resource consumption rate.\nSo far the game seems incredible, until they introduce the second campaign... there are so many random events with litttle to no explaination of solving them... such as poison fish, special build technologies, or most frustratingly telling you oil is available and buildable until a special event occurs. For a tutorial based campagin, all this game does, is confuse me... After roughly 10 hours I am confused and annoyed.

reviewText:
3 Stars - An immersive build game, that can be a pleasure to play.

When I first got into this game I fell straight into it. Well build and beautiful I enjoyed mining the varied resources and searching through the tech trees to build my ultimate city and expand.

However over time the immersion was lost. The game can be quite slow and the end game was unrewarding. After a reasonable play time I found that many objectives offered too little for too much. Multiplayer attempts failed to work well, and too often the map just seemed to run out, leaving goals unmanageable.

Overall, if this is your style of game you will get a lot out of your first 30 odd hours of playtime but by 60 expect the cracks to start to appear.

Pros -
Immersive
Well designed resource and tech combinations
Varying approaches
Pretty

Cons -
Lack End Game vision
Can be slow paced
Multiplayer is not worth your time

reviewText:
Anno 2070 is very much like it's predecessors, however, the polished look and feel of the interface, nicely balanced units, and cross building between the various careers (factions), and coupled with that ever so slight appeal of future tech and possible future make it shine all on it's own.

For those who don't know, the Anno series is a city builder / real-time strategy game, leaning a bit more heavily on the builder aspects. Managing the needs of your sector and cities within can sometimes be a juggling act in itself. If you're looking for the pace and speed of say Command & Conquer or Starcraft. This isn't for you. If liked those games, and also liked things like SimCity or other builders I think you'll enjoy this.

The amazing emmersive soundtrack, and top notch voice work, splended visuals, and solid gameplay really add up to an enjoyable experience be it for a quick daily mission game or, whole evening dive into continuous play. With multiple game modes, multiplayer drop-in, world-events, user interactions through elections and making choses, advancing up your career ladder. The Anno 2070 is a game that could keep you busy for months.

reviewText:
Starting up the game is a trial itself. I spent around half an hour just to get it running. And even then, it was riddled with crashes (5 crashes in under 20 min)

If anyone is interested in how to get it running at least once:
First, I had to enter the key, and wait for the uplay installer to update the recently downloaded game.
Then uplay started crashing, had to enter go to the Anno 2070 installation folder, right click the game.exe and set it to win xp compatibility mode. The game will refuse to launch through steam as it will crash on startup, you must open it directly through the game folder game.exe.
After setting up the uplay account, which again asked for the key, I was able to start the game.

I thought my troubles would end there, however.... The game crashed 4 times in the first campaign mission (3 of which were during the last cinematic, and the fact that Anno doesn't seem to have an auto-save is even more irritating). I inicially thought it was a problem in only the first campaign mission, but the second mission crashed 2 minutes in, I gave up playing after that.

Although I played for an extremely limited amount of time, I have to say. Anno 2070 would have been a great game if it were playable, I've seen many early access titles more stable than this game.

reviewText:
Annoying and unintuitive.

Launching the game launches Ubisoft's UPlay, which requires you to set up an account.  Annoying.  Finally get through that and some graphical issues causing the game to minimize on startup to find that, yes the game itself now wants me to set up an account!  Annoying.  Do that and then, oh we need to restart to download updates!  Annoying.  Finally reboot and get the game to launch and log in.  It's been an hour.  Frustrated.  Try to figure out exactly what I'm supposed to do at this main menu of sorts.... end up clicking on quick start to the campaign.  Game session begins.  No tutorial.  Start clicking around to see whats up and clicking on the Ark (the main building platform) and this has the effect of muting and dismissing the guy in the top right trying to tell me what I need to do to complete this mission.  No idea what to do.  Game isn't helping.

Don't buy this game unless you enjoy setting up various pointless accounts and being thrown into a gameplay environment with zero tutorial.

reviewText:
The climate has changed, sea levels have risen… What a great time for a strategy game! Anno 2070 is a futuristic real-time strategy game focused on city management and colonization. The game provides a good campaign that deals with the kind-of-steep learning curve. Harvest resources, explore new land and waters, engage in diplomacy and much more.

The gameplay is very smooth and well made, the graphics and sound quality is excellent. There are global community votes that actually effect how the game is played, I found this to be a nice little feature to include. Developing your cities takes time, this does get tedious during certain moments of the game, but usually you can find something to do while you wait for whatever it is you're doing.

Anno 2070 is a great strategy game and has me going for several hours at a time, even though the game asks me to take a break every hour I find it hard to put down!

Ubisoft support just gives an automate written email at hand with a lot of oppurtunities to solve the problem. Shutting down ur DHCP-service for example. However, in my case nothing worked at all and unfortunately it seems to me, like Ubisoft doesn't care much at all about it.
I'm really a great fan of the Anno-series and played it from the beginning, so I'm right sure this sequel is minimum as good and addicting as the last ones, but since I can't run it, it doesn't matter to me. However, u might be lucky and it will run fine, like it does in other cases, but by reading this be intensly warned.
In my case I'm truly fond of supporting developing games I like by buying them original, like I was by buying Anno2070, but for now it seems to me, that there isn't any solution than cracking the game, what means giving the multiplayer a miss.

reviewText:
The game itself is makes a very good impression, but there are a few points that totally destroy the fun with it.

1.) Like with many other games you have to install a completely useless tool (UPlay) to play the game. Not only is the tool frequently broken, it programmed so badly it slows down the computer.

2.) Features in the Solo-Game nead online connection. When in the description is written I need a connection for multiplayer mode, I expect ALL solo features to work without it, otherwise you have to write the game needs a connection not only one mode of it. Clear case of customer misinformation to increase sales.

3.) The AI of the NPCs is totally screwed up, as they build no cities. All there settlements seam to be a randomly scattered collection of a few building-types, even if these sets of buildings vary between different NPCs  it looks just strange.

4.) Bugs. I frequently encountered bugs like, complete reset of all researched technologies, boni that were substracted instead of added and so on.
voteText: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
So much to do with hours of fun. Many empires to build and enemies to defeat. Oh did I mention underwater Bases too? Game is detailed on all levels from economy, trading, diplomacy, etc. Combat though can be a bit weak, but makes up for it in natural disasters, like oil spills (if you have oil rigs or someone else does) Tsunamis’ if you have the proper DLC, and various infections that can poison your empires food supply.

Having to counter those disasters can take a while if you’re not prepared for it.
Still getting into the game myself, and must say the game is a great buy. I would definitely recommend it, especially if you have friends to play with.

On that note, This review is based solely off of the game itself. No DRM negative review because DRM and UPlay sucks. I could care less, as I already had a Uplay account and the game was easily linked with no problems.
voteText: 13 of 21 people (62%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I love the predecessor games AD 1701 and AD 1401, but this one isn't good. Preachy environmentalism and forcedly-corrupt capitalism turned a great franchise into a downer.

AD 1701 has a fun, happy, Caribbean feel to it. AD 1401 is super complex but awesome mechanically, with a West-meets-East setting.  They are both impeccably polite and perfectly British.

2070 has none of the charm of its earlier games and makes no real improvements to playability or mechanics.  Let's hope the next Anno game is better.

reviewText:
I'm sure this game will be/is fantastic IF you can get the mandatory online play part to work.
Just purchased yesterday. I have spent 30 minutes so far navigating the jargon of Ubisoft, and I am NOT pleased with my experience.
I even have an excellent gaming PC and fantastic internet ability, but the company is crap for requiring always-online server play. It nullifies the experience, especially when Ubisoft seems unable to actually provide the type of networking they need.

It's all bull and I won't buy another of their games EVER again. They were even keen to make me use another form because I happen to be several months under the age of 18, which I completely understand, but it would be nice if the website they directed me to was actually available.

The poor planning behind what looks like a beautiful experience has made me less keen to enjoy it. I'm glad I paid only $13 instead of the rediculous $50 price of the regular bundle. What baffoons these developers are! I'd even go as far to say it's worse than the launch of SimCity 2013. And that's saying something.

Long rant short: great game, I love what I see, however, if your computer and ISP aren't up to the challenge, abandon all hope of getting to enjoy it. Meanwhile, I'm going to try again to actually play.

reviewText: There are a lot of reviews knocking the Uplay login required to play this game; and it was pretty bad. While it is still there, they have streamlined it with Steam so you don't interact with it after your first play. If you discount this, rather glaring, issue with the game; this is one of my favorite of the Anno series--and even of all city building games. There is a lot of spectacular visuals to look at and a good balance of depth and strategy to it. I would refer anyone who likes their city building games with a little sci-fi/fantasy in it to give this game a try.

reviewText: Took a leap of faith with this one. Never played any of the other Anno games but was intrigued by the concept. Lucky I did. The gameplay was fantastic, graphics were beautiful. The story was short but good. One thing I really love about the game is the replay value. Trying to get your culture to the pinnacle of society and combining the other factions to help was awesome. The game can be lengthy which in my opinion is great. The combat could have been done slightly better. Not a fan of requiring the Tech's airplanes to finish off islands or waiting for your boats to starve them out by taking out the ports. Overall a very great game
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game, first and foremost, is the most expansive, intricate city-builder I have ever played.  The number of structures, units, etc. is stunning.  There are three different, largely unique buildings tracks, each with their own style and appearance.  The fun part is mastering each and then using them together.  While the diplomacy and combat are somewhat rudimentary, they are adequate and add a further level of complexity to already intricate gameplay.  Moreover, it is a gorgeous game.  You will play this game for one hundred hours and still be amazed by it.

The problem, of course, is getting past the first 5-10 hours.  This game has a very large learning curve and has almost no tutorial. What tutorial exists is a very bad one.  I believe this is why this game has received bad reviews in the past.

Overall, I would recommend this game highly, if you have the endurance to learn its gameplay.  And I am writing this having not even purchased a single DLC.  I can’t wait to do so.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Literally, a ground-breaking concept of SimCity and Online multiplaying. Not only you can play multiplayers: players vote decisions that affect everyone else's decision and some aspects of gameplay. Truly, it's inspiring and a remarkable game for anyone who likes either good strategy or good micro-manegement.\n\nLiteralmente, uma experiência conceitual autêntica de SimCity e jogos multiplayer. Não simplesmente por poder jogar multiplayer: jogadores votam em decisões que afetam as decisões e parte do jogo de todos os outros jogadores. Realmente, é inspirador, marcante, empolgante e com muito conteúdo pra ser jogado por muito tempo - bom para qualquer um que goste de estratégia ou de micro-gerenciamento.

reviewText: I was pretty disappointed with this game. The campaign does an insufficient job of explaining the parameters you are expected to operate within, and the free play lobs ridiculous and unnecessary obstacles at you (like starting you on an island that cannot support the medium level upgrades necessary to develop your civilization). The game play is severely extended to the point where it's beneficial to leave the game running for 30 min unattended to mine the resources necessary to advance another 10 min. The graphics are undeniably stunning, and the soundtrack incredible, but this is unfortunately icing on an otherwise pretty bland cake.\n\nAfter 15 hours of getting annoyed and flabbergasted at trying to figure out what I thought must surely be a pretty good game, I have given up. May your results fair better than my own if you elect to try this game out.

reviewText:
The older Anno games are superior in every way except graphics, and the graphics on this one are so overdone that this game, an RTS, over-stressed my video card more than any other game I own, which includes all CryEngine games. The initial experience is that it patches the patcher to patch the updater which updates the initial installation of uPlay garbage that Ubisoft inflicts upon you in order that you might eventually be allowed to play the game. After 5 patching screens, I get the UPlay program open, and still no way to play the actual game. Had to kill uPlay with task manager and restart, and finally got uPlay to acknowledge that, yes, I have the right to run the game. Thank you. Can I play now? No, actually, I need to put up with in-game ad for ANNO online, and a request to go fill out a survey about my ANNO playing experience on Survey Monkey. Really, guys? Are you serious?!

When you do get to play, I find it to be too much story, too many distractions from game-characters, and campaign scenarios that are uneven in quality. For example, where you need to just build a city that produces so much fish, and then the scenario is over. Weak. It is also uneven in hand-holding, where I found it irritating to be told exactly what to do next, and then suddenly run into a situation where I had no idea of what to do to get some stat up to the critical level for the hokey scenario to finish.

As a game, it isn't terrible. If your video card is less than three years old, you might be OK on that front, though my dual-GPU card was definitely stressed to the point of an early heat-death... that was on the lowest settings, to be clear. On my new system, at the time of writing this, it works very quietly on the lowest settings. Now that I've reloaded it on my new system, I will probably enjoy it more, but my earlier experience has soured me on Ubisoft, and ANNO 2070, certainly.

It is, underneath the hokey storlline, an ANNO game in the end. But for me, I just cannot get over having to put up with the idiocy that is uPlay. I've promised myself to never pay money for a UbiSoft game again, due to that crap.

It's pretty. Underneath a butt-load of flourishes, bells, and overdone whistles, it is an ANNO game. But, I recommend dropping back to a previous ANNO and playing that instead.

reviewText:
I am here after about 3 hours of getting the stupid game to work.  The game has three major points of failure. Here has been my process.

Buy game through steam.
Download and update through steam.
Launching the game actually launches Ubisoft's terrible UPlay.
Uplay then asks for the activation key, which I then enter.
Uplay attempts to redownload the entire game. I cancel it.
Uplay now has 2 entries in the games list for anno; one for steam and one I'd have to redownload.
I click the other one, and it launches through steam (yes, steam launches uplay which launches anno through steam).
Anno then decides to update. There are now 3 updaters for this ONE game.
Anno launches, and once again asks for my cd key (why??) and for me to log into uplay (although I *launched* this from uplay).
It crashed a few times after this, but finally it took my cd key and told me that I have to restart anno to access the DLC; it gave me no choice than to restart the game.
I restarted the game, and it took several attempts to even connect to their server to download the DLC.

In sum: This game will only  work if steam, uplay, and the anno servers ALL work and are responding, and the process of even activating and authenticating yourself as a customer is hell.

reviewText:
1.  I'm not sure what Uplay is or what it does, but I don't like having it forced on me.  If it offers me something worthwhile, then I'll opt in.  Not giving me a choice simply shows that you have no confidence that I'd opt in if given the choice.  If you have no confidence in what your own software offers the consumer, then why should I?

2.  Between all the patching and updating and trying to figure out what Uplay was and why it wouldn't just let me play the game and registering and being told I couldn't play in offline mode, it took me about 45min to get to the game's main menu.

3.  The game felt eco-preachy right off the bat.  This isn't what I'm looking for in a game.

4.  If the game has a tutorial of any sort, I couldn't find it.  I figured it must be built into the campaign, but that didn't seem to be the case either.  Instead of a mission walking me through the game mechanics, I'm given some terse orders and vague goals with no clue as to how to reach them.

5.  I was feeling plenty grumpy by this point and remembered I have a number of other games waiting for my time in my Steam library.  So I decided to go play them instead.  I doubt I'll be back.  You only get one chance to make a good first impression, Ubisoft.

reviewText:
This is a beautiful game, easy to pick up and with a user-friendly interface. But set against the backdrop of its predecessors, I can't recommend it. Every time I opened it up I was left feeling saddened by the missed opportunity.

There is a built-in conflict described between the eco-focused and development-focused factions, but this conflict isn't enforced by the game's resource exploitation models and tech trees. They took it halfway there with an eco-damage mechanic, but the two factions should have been forced to adopt diametrically opposed progress conditions, rather than the carbon copy mechanics we see here.

An example: both sides possess the same number of housing tech levels, with the same mechanic for evolving them (population numbers plus availability of secondary goods). Since there is very little crossover of secondary goods, there is no tension between eco and development factions when reaching the highest goal - the ecos don't care about lobsters and champagne, and there's enough rice farms to go around.

Instead, we should have seen the developers require huge numbers of tightly-packed houses to advance, coupled with a flourishing economy; and the ecos requiring a low number of big-footprint houses coupled with minimal environmental impact. This means that the factions would always find it hard to coexist at the top development levels, and it'd always occur to one or the other that things would be so much simpler if the other's stuff would just start blowing up.

Which leads to the second problem. The tactical and strategic combat wasn't thought through very well at all. Put simply, you don't make rock-paper-scissors work better by restricting the number of choices players have. All three flavours of combat units - air, land, sea - should be available, and the balance between them should be a determining strategic factor. Strengths versus weaknesses. Instead we have a world with NO land-based forces except for the occasional (and limited) turret, restricted air availability, and a poor tech advancement tree.

A caveat on the last: there is actually a brilliant research and development tree available via the scientist faction. Unfortunately, it doesn't have the impact on gameplay that it deserves. There is no need to pursue a technological race with your adversary, since it's far more efficient to just spam out more low-tech units.

Makes me sad, considering how brilliant parts of this game are. Lost opportunity. Then again, maybe I should just get off my ♥♥♥♥ and learn modding, since the game is well supported in this area.

reviewText:
My mind is twisted about this game. Sure, it looks fantastic and at first glance has a lot of depth. After I bought it I was very excited of finally calling it my own. But that's where the trouble started. The Ubisoft launcher is a catastrophy to put it mildly. It took hours for countless updates to install and I had to enter my serials three times. Needless to say that my excitement about the game shrank considerably. The whole point of buying games on steam for me is to avoid all the nasty installation procedures, click a button and more or less start playing. The only good news here is, that after going through the hellfire of the initial installation the launcher is less agonizing. Still it may take 10 Minutes to just launch the game. Big fail.

When you can FINALLY start to play you're pretty much on your own in a world you know only little about. There's a campaign mode which I tried to start with. Quickly I ran into trouble just because I couldn't figure out what to do in order to fulfill the goals. The game doesn't teach you at all. I abandoned the campaign mode and went for the sandbox. Youtube videos on how to play the game helped me to make some progress and pretty soon I settled on a bunch of islands doing great. The game became fun! Big plus ...

But that was about all I got. The game just became stale. There was nothing left to do. So the few moments of excitement went away and now I can't be bothered to turn the game on again. What a shame, but this game is honestly one of the most boring and repeatative games I have ever played. Despite it's beauty and appearant depth, there just isn't much of a challenge left to it once you've played for a few hours.

So I'm sorry to say that I can't recommend this great but utterly boring game. The ubisoft launcher alone kinda kills it to begin with, but the gameplay just didn't manage to excite me enough to forget about this.

reviewText:
I don't recommend this game for only one reason - Anno 1404, its predacessor, is SO much better.

This entry in the series is a technical advance, but it has taken the organic feel of 1404 and sterilised it, losing a lot in the process. Much of the appeal of the original was finding your own solution to a very broad set of objectives, but 2070 adds a campaign that provides a rigid structure to the missions that feels far too constrained, and it has thrown in additional mechanics that serve only to restrict how you can build and interact with the world.

If you enjoy these kinds of management games, I'd recommend picking up 1404 plus its expansion, Venice, before even considering Anno 2070.

reviewText:
Before i begine. I WILL NOT COUNT ANY ISSUES WITH U-PLAY AS ISSUES WITH THIS GAME! (those who do downvote and ruin a great game based on issues with the drm system that isnt THIS games fault.) All in All, this is a fun game. Its full of a rather LARGE number of things to do if you get the final, complete version. has quite a bit of gameplay mechanics to learn and enjoy, and so long as your patient, can give  you plenty of challenges to enjoy. the learning curve isnt overwhelming but there is one to it, but as with any city builder/resource management game, thats to be expected. all in alll i give this game

Graphics:9/10 (a few issues here and there with graphical bugs but mostly perfection)

Sound 10/10 (the music is beautiful, with decent sound effects and good quality to sound placement (and a few funny things from your dwellers if you zoom in on them)

Story 7/10 (This game lacks somewhat in the story department. It does have a story but nothing grand or utterly new. As you would expect, Nature, Money, Science, Take a choice and the story follows.)

Gui/Controles 8/10 (the controles feel pretty natural for a game of this type, though there where some issues finding things in the GUI at first. The controles and keys can be remapped in game which is a plus and once you learn the basic locations of things, it gets really easy)

Overall 8.5/10 (Go and play this game. you will enjoy it)

*side note* I have never experianced ANY issues ever with uplay. I have, however, Seen plenty of issues both here and with friends, dealing with the DRM system crashing. I recommend you download uplay from ubisoft and make sure that, not only can you run it, but that you find out what is causing the crash in the first place (most of the issues and solutions can be found online, with a short google search. The game issue i found with friends is that it wasnt installed using Admin mode or run under admin mode with windows 7 and up)

reviewText:
I would dearly love to review this game - I'm a fan of the series overall and it looks quite brilliant.

I can't though, because it doesn't appear in my UPlay library. There's a very clear reason why I use Steam for games:

1) Click 'Play'
2) I am now playing

Here's how my evening has broken down so far:

1) Click 'Play'
2) Installing Ubisoft Game Launcher
3) Autopatching
4) Autopatcher has crashed - repeat steps 1 - 3
5) Would you like to configure the graphics now?
6) Installing UPlay
7) Updating UPlay
8) Create a UPlay account!
9) Log in to UPlay
10) No game appears in my UPlay library

So, half an hour and a considerable amount of patience later. It's like someone at Ubisoft is scared of making money or something. I can honestly say I won't be buying anything else from them until they ditch their ridiculous DRM. UPlay is an abominable system, but a good advert for Steam? reviewText: Bought this game as a good way to excercise memory and multitasking skills. The other game aspects such as missions and graphics are satisfactory and graphics are ok for mid range computing power. Noticed some slight bugs but otherwise pretty solid as a game build. I purchased game on a Steam sale but I would have regretted paying full price. The fun factor is only 5 out of 10. IF the micro-managing was made simpler and game play focusing more on building and battle tactics then this would have been a fun game. I would only recommend this to supertaskers, but because I am a casual to mid range gamer I would have to say purchase only when the price is in the bargain territory.

reviewText: The game is pretty and solidly made.  However, it's not that interesting playing after a few times because the optimal action to take is always the same. The lack of wiggle room, fuziness, and randomness makes city & unit building a mechanical task and a chore.\n\nThis migh not be an issue if you play the game for the combat, but if that's the case there are plenty of interesting RTS out there more focused on combat.  I'm hoping that the next Anno would put the excitement of city building back in the game.

reviewText:
For those of us looking for a top notch economic simulator with a focus on strategic city building, Anno 2070 will scratch that itch and then some.  You'll be expanding accross a number of islands (and viable plots of ocean floor) on each map that produce and grow independently from one another which makes creating trade routes imperative if you hope to make them prosper in the long run.  A fun campaign injects a story and special objectives into the game, but the large number of maps available keeps Anno 2070 playable for a long time after that.

Your colonies themselves have a lot of customization available as you would imagine with a city builder.  Three different population types are available each with their own unique perks that they can offer.  There are the money-obsessed, capitalism-loving Tycoons, the beauty and clean living Ecos, and the science fanatics known as the Techs.  Each has several tiers of classes to unlock within them as long as you meet their ever-growing list of demands.  Workers may not ask for much but executives will require a significant, continued supply of resources that will take some commitment to produce.

Creating and maintaining trade routes requires a level of micromanagement but when you hit that sweet spot and start shipping the near-perfect quantity of a resource from your single colony that produces it to all of your colonies that use it to produce more advanced goods you feel an incredible sense of accomplishment.  Watching the economy thrive and grow after having built it from the ground up is fantastic feeling.

I recommend this game to anyone and everyone who enjoys city builders and economy simulators.  This is easily one of the best ones that I have played.  Few games of the genre manage to reach the depth of Anno 2070 (pun intended?) and I still start the game up from time to time even having completed the campaign quite some time ago.

reviewText: ANNO 2070 is the perfect game for everyone who loves to tweak an economy and build large scale cities. Especially the endgame is really complex with many things to do. Anno 2070 pushes the series to incredible highs and is amongst the best in its genre. The easy to learn controls and rules, new online options and the way you can build while preserving nature all make this the best strategy game of 2011.The developers have succeeded in creating a game faithful to the tradition and at the same time a game full of new elements and mechanics, that make it feel fresh. All that, plus a great campaign and a variety of multiplayer options make Anno 2070 an excellent game and even some technical issues can't change that.Ubisoft made a great decision in taking the Anno franchise to the future. Trading, building, doing quests, there is a ton of stuff to do. It's very interesting to see the environment play a big role and the effects of polution add a great new gameplay concept. Anno 2070 really is all about building and trading and won't be fulfilling for people that are looking to rage war.It's about expansion, trading, economics, boats, and staring at a lot of awfully pretty sci-fi buildings while you do so... which, frankly, is more than an enough for me.Glancing 60 years into the future and learning from old mistakes, Related Designs made a masterpiece.

reviewText:
When i seen Anno 2070 on the steam sale, i was pretty happy. It appears to follow the path of the previous anno games which where great fun (even the one on the DS). However, i have not actually had the chance to play anno 2070 yet, due to the amount of time it took to update the game itself after download (expected). As i was greeted with the request for a serial key, i had to remind myself that it wasnt 2006 and that i did buy this game on steam (supposed to stop this), but ok, its only a few clicks ill roll with it. As i progressed though this, i was then greeted with a SECOND digital distrobution platform.. uplay. Hold on, did i not buy this game on steam? no uplay, uplay why are you updating.. ok ill wait. About 30 mins later, i was bored and lost a large chunk of my playtime for that session.

A few days later i thought, hey uplay will be updated, ill give this another blast... uplay was not fully updated and took another 30 mins or so to get me updated. A which point i was greeted with a login screen within uplay... WHY is this game forcing me to sign into two platforms?

TLDR: The game has a dual digital distribution, requireing two online accounts to use. Why? no idea. I will add, that i have not yet actually managed to play the game.

reviewText:
When I bought this game, I didn't realise it had Uplay.

When I opened it for the first time, it started this app called Uplay. I had to create an account with Uplay, which was inconvenient and I didn't want another account just to play this game.

Then, after Uplay opened, I couldn't figure out how to start the game, so I quit Uplay, and clicked Play Game from Steam again.

Then finally, Uplay launched, but it had to auto update. Then it asked me to add the game to my Uplay account. I already bought the game on Steam, why do I need to register it a 2nd time?

Then again, nothing happened, Uplay was just sitting there, and I quit it. Then I clicked Play Game from Steam again. This time Uplay launched, then the game launched. Once in the game, it asked me for the product key, which I had to cut and paste from Steam. It told me that the game would be registered against my Uplay account, but haven't I already done that?

Then, I had to create a profile in the game. The game then told me that it was installing some addons (???) and had to download them and restart. I clicked Okay, and the game promptly crashed (Anno 2070 has stopped working").

I launched it from Steam again
date: which told me the game was already running. I found some weird updater GUI running minimised with some EULA agreement. Then on my (slow) internet connection
