reviewText:
Anno 2070 - Complete Edition is a strategy city building simulator. Decades after the global warming that melted the polar caps and changed the face of the Earth, you are put in charge of an Ark: an aquatic base of operation that travels the seas to establish new settlements on oceanic islands, managing economy, resource exploitation and relations with other factions. This review includes all DLCs and the Deep Ocean expansion set.

Pros: This is a great addition to the Anno series, this time taking place in the fairly-near future without going too sci-fi (that's for Anno 2205 to do). Like past iterations of the franchise, you start with a limited amount of resources and must build industries with to make more building material. Citizen classes are upgraded by providing commodities, and the quantity of citizens you have of each various classes will unlock more buildings and options. The game looks great, factions are easily recognizable and the islands are gorgeous. You can play a continuous free-mode game or pick from a large selection of mission challenges. You also have a campaign mode which is a great gradual introduction to the evolving selection of buildings and to the factions you can side with. You pick between the economically-strong Global Trust or the ecologically-sustaining Eden Initiative factions, and can also ally yourself to the scientific and underwater-expert S.A.A.T. faction. The Uplay community is actually made use of for something else than serving as a DRM: the various factions will regularly put up proposals players can vote on, there are online elections to pick a governing faction that will offer changing bonuses, and the game downloads a temporary mission-of-the-day" Daily Event.

Cons: The game doesn't have an actual tutorial
date: so even the introductory campaign will leave you wondering whether the next step is a building
hoursPlayed: or an upgrade. Combat was obviously not the focus of the game which makes PvP multiplayer games hard to win. Although all three factions have different buildings and citizen needs
voteText: they ultimately are the same thing with different name on them: Global Trust uses has Distilleries while Eden Initiative has Tea Plantations
helpfulPercent: S.A.A.T. has a production chain for Carbon while Global Trust has one for Concrete
votesHelpful: etc. The material a faction can't make itself is material it simply doesn't make use of
votesTotal:
so there is little need to trade with other factions.

Verdict: ★★★★☆ - Next on your list

This is a great city builder! Like other games of the Anno series
votesFunny: it's very different to manage building material and citizens commodities than the usual complexities of budget
commentsCount: taxes and municipal services. If you enjoyed past games of the franchise
column16: or simply want to try a different formula than the other City Builders out there
column17: I strongly recommend giving Anno 2070 - Complete Edition a try!\n\nP.S.: The included Uplay appears to be broken for many people

so you must manually download the latest version (which you can do here[static3.cdn.ubi.com]) or the game may not work at all. That's too bad for what is essentially a good game.
—————————————————————————
This was just my opinion.

reviewText:
This game will take chunks out of your spare time and consume them until it's the next morning when you look away from the screen. Build your cities, take over islands and create a stable economy. Survive against the harsh enviroment changes as you turn the green islands into either even greener or into grey industrial dumps. Manage your resources and protect your caravans as your opponents do the same.

The game itself is very slow but rewarding the further you go. Single misstakes will turn your production chains into dust so be careful.

Pro: Fun and rewarding experience

Con: Extremly time consuming to get anywhere

reviewText:
I bought this game about a year and a half ago during the steam summer sale of 2013. I enjoyed the game at first, and learned about U-Play.... If I enjoyed it then why did I not recommend the game? I don't reccomend the game because I think that the core gameplay is dis-functional, and it's mostly notices after various games. This is a long review but in-depth. Read on for more info.

Engine:
Let me start out by saying that ever time, before i launch the game, i have to validate the game files or else the game crashes randomly. I looked it up and this is a known engine bug that existed in the last Anno games as well. Ubisoft must not have thought that the game-breaking bug needed to be fixed. (Remind you of any recent Ubisoftness)

-Pros/Cons:
+ It CAN work
----- Bad Engine
-- Crashes

General Gameplay:

Let me start out by noting there are two player factions which change looks and core gameplay. Power production and even the resources you need to get to the new tiers change. I only have played with the Tycoons since they are my style but they both look fun. I've never taken the time to play extensively with the Initative. More details can be found below on each aspect of gameplay.

++ Diversity

- Resources:
The gameplay is supply chain and resource production. You build your iron mines, smelt it into steel, and then produce tools from the steel. Managing the buildings, citizens, supply and demand, food, and fleet can be a challenge at times. If you are into micro managing things than you're probably going to like the gameplay.

-Pros/Cons: ~Meh
+- Supply chain
+- Management

-Economy:
The problems arise in balance however. You start out with little money, barely enough to get your island under control and produce more. Often the money ammount is so low i cannot get the revenue i need, even through trading, to keep my island running smoothly, so that has made me loose many times. The money will make you loose more often than a war.

-Pros/Cons: ~OH MY GOD HELP ME!!!!
--- Horrible economic start, you start behind
-- You'll keep encountering money issues until the late game
+ More citizens = more taxes = more money
- Diplomacy

-War:
Speaking of war, war is bad. The AI start with a fully developed Island and fleet, not you however. This screws with the balance. Ships can really only start to be made in the mid-game, and AI has a fleet in the beggining. Even when you get the materials to make ships (supply chain) you can not make much ships. If by this point you have done something horrible, like building a building that makes the AI mad at you (more on this in a little bit), it's game over. Ships are so hard to build at the start i've only ever had one game where I could even produce ships, but I only ever made two because of the budget (money issues again). Im not sure how well balances war is if everyone has ships, i've never had more than one attacking ship.

-Pros/Cons: ~Dunno, I'VE NEVER BEEN ABLE TO WAGE WAR!
----- Horribly unbalanced, game ruining
-- AI always ahead
-- Hard to make any fleet to defend
-- money needed to do anything cool with a fleet
++ no excessive micro managing during battles

-Diplomacy:
If you ever try and use diplocy you will be mad. Diplomacy isn't like civ where your trading resouces, it's just you paying the AI for services, like delaying another AI, not expanding, ect.. The prices are steep so you'll most likely never have the money you need to do what you want done until the end game (more spending). If you're in the end game I don't see why you would nbeed their services though. As I mentioned earlier, the only actual diplomacy is where you do something that pisses the AI off and they send you a threat. You have two options, follow through with the demands or declare war. YAY for options.... If you actually have a fleet by the time you receive the threat you might be able to fight.

-Pros/Cons: ~Never used
-- Useless
+-- AI Threats

!! Example: I needed oil to start a new production line and get to the next tier, so I expanded and build oil wells. Then I receive a threat from the oil baron AI, Destroy all your oil wells and production or declare war." I couldn't destroy my oil without consequences and didn't have the money to just buy his oil (More economy issues
date: again) so I was forced to declare war. I thought it would't be that bad and he'd just leave me alone mostly
recommended:
but he charged in with high level warships and leveled my main island...

Island colonization:
I actually liked this gameplay aspect. You can colonize other islands and produce good that can't be grown on your main island (depending on the island). Then you can create an automated trade route to exchange resources. The only problem is that you need a cargo ship
hoursPlayed: so one will always be busy. If you want to trade also you'll need at least two cargo ships or to stop the transport temporarily. If you need two ships you'd better be able to build the second one
voteText: so you'll need money (wow
helpfulPercent:
more money needed. Cargo ships are the easiest ships to make though). If you chose to repurpose the main ship then it can stop the production chain which can cause unhappy citizens and then tax problems leading to a ruined economy in the long run (...).

-Pros/Cons: ~I Enjoyed it
++ Different islands
+ You can intercept transports to ruin a players economy (works both ways)
+ Underwater islands (This is more late game so i've never been able to use them)
- Could maybe use even more island diversity

Graphics:
Now since im over with the gameplay let go into graphics. Not too bad actually. Futuristic looking
votesHelpful: of course
votesTotal:
so sleek building and interesting vehicles. Good graphics overall.

Pros/Cons: ~Good
++ Futuristic
+ Nice looking islands

Sound:
It's been a while since I've played and I mostly forget the sounds of the game
votesFunny:
but I don't remember anything annoying me so thats a big plus. All i remember is that I liked it

Pros/Cons: ~?
++ Nothing annoying
+ It works

The Verdict:
Buy this game if the gameplay is your style
commentsCount: you could enjoy it more than me.\n\n-For me though 5/10."

reviewText:
Don't buy this on Steam.  Just don't.  Buy it elsewhere, because it's usable there.  Anno 2070 is essentially the block before Simcity 2014, by a different AAA publisher.  Always online DRM, launching through Uplay, and really-sketchy Steam integration makes this game impossible to recommend for the majority of audiences that want to play it for the first time.

A few notes before the game critique:
You can still resolve issues with Uplay by installing Uplay before downloading and activating this game through Steam.  There's some manual patching you need to do, but that does put off a large portion of the audience.  Pick it up if you're willing to put in the effort to get it working; as of late 2015, Ubisoft hasn't addressed any of the fundamental problems with getting it running
Make sure you have a machine you'll play through the entire game with, because this Steam version acts as one copy.  I can't play this copy anymore because I upgraded to Windows 10; and thus my previous machine (which I can't go back to) has this copy on it.  Make sure you've got it on a medium that Ubisoft trusts you to have it with, be it on Uplay originally or a physical copy.
This is not the game for you if you don't have great internet.  If you lose access to Uplay servers, you could forfeit your current work even on the single-player campaign.
The ProsAnno 2070 is a gorgeous addition to the series that adds a lot of addicting features.  Citizen management, faction alliances and tech research all feel much more interwoven than in previous titles, and given the futuristic asthetic, it seems pretty coherent.

Though I don't think it was executed as well as it could have been, the story mode was very immersive and I found the real-world themes of industry vs environmentalism to be very engaging.  There's different styles you can set things up to appeal to the masses and obviously multitudes of methods to accomplish those means, which I found very encouraging for me to find my own solutions to problems I had (usually) brought upon myself.

The ConsAs a first time player, this was really, really hard for me to get into.  I actually went back and played Anno 1503 to sort of understand what the game was asking for and to acquire a general feel for how it's played.  Thereafter, though I like the very high-tech and modern feel of the game, I don't think the intro or tutorial to the game were well done at all.  Having gone through it's predacessors, I struggled re-learning the specifics of new units and buildings, as well as having the map  awareness or sense of scale to do quests at apropriate times.  It's a very challenging game, and it mostly leaves itself for the player to figure out.

My VerdictAnno 2070 is a game you likely won't play, and will regret not doing so.  Though it's built on the previous titles quite a bit, I don't think it inhibited my progress at any point and kept me coming back for more.  I ended up sinking" many more hours in this installment than I did in 1503
date:
and hope to play 2205 soon.

8.25/10

However in the current setup on Steam/Uplay
recommended: I do not recommend purchasing this game for the sake of your future playing it.  Anno isn't a game to be played for 5-10 hours and then put down - heavens no.  This is something that I find rivals Age of Empires
hoursPlayed: and you might end up sinking well over a hundred hours into it.  If you lose your copy (like I did) you would have been better off buying it somewhere else.\n"

reviewText:
A disappointing sequel to Anno 1404 (Dawn of Discovery) which, in my opinion, doesn't add enough to the previous game to be justified.  Features such as the underwater islands are an interesting touch, but there is little that you can actually do with them.  Everything else about the game is just Anno 1404 with a few new building types and new names for everything.  I'm all for sequels to good games sticking with the format that works, but they have to add enough content to justify their price tag, and this one didn't.

As if to add insult to injury, the game also REQUIRES Ubisoft's UPlay launcher to start the game, which REQUIRES you to have a UPlay account (yet another username and password) and be always connected to the internet.  Aside from the fact that I object to this type of publisher account where it adds no value to the game for the consumer, but the software itself is unreliable and often fails to connect or crashes before I can even play the game.  Not to mention that this is on top of the existing TAGES DRM which imposes the 3 machine activation limit that was present in Anno 1404.

All in all, I would recommend people play Anno 1404 (with the Venice expansion pack) instead and save themselves the heavy price tag and immense frustration for a game that adds little to the fantastic Anno series.

reviewText:
This is one of the best strategy games I've played. Got the complete edition on sale and got my friends to get it also and it has been really fun. It has a lot of neat elements to it and is complex enough to stay interesting and not be overly complicated to the point where it's not fun. The graphics are really nice in my opinion, especially when you go underwater and build cool stuff on underwater plateaus. It's really fun with 4 players but you can play with more if you're willing to co-op with another person, bringing the count up to 8 players.

The factions in the game are very different so the gameplay really changes with each, but late game you are able to unlock all of the other factions which is cool too. My main complaint about the factions is that if you pick the Eco faction and you are playing against an agressive tycoon, you likely won't be able to defend yourself for a while so you have to figure out other ways to protect your islands.

I really like this game, give it a try!

reviewText:
back when SETTLERS was a thing age of empire was eating the market... building + management of the buildings and not the units was confusing for all the AOE players...then anno came after... and it all changed...anno is a game where you gotta think 10 game hours before you do anything... take off your age of empire spectacles and enter a game were you NEED to manage over 50 ressources ... at the same time... youll need to produce spices ( if your island has that ressource unlocked ..because each island on the map has different ''seeds'' that limits what you can exploit off that island)  and meat to make hamburgers for your tycoons and satisfy 1 need out of the 7 they suggest... 1 need can be 3 goods to manage... and theres combat too on top of that...because theres so much into building a warship ..you will need to use it wisely because loosing it can hurt you big time.

your main goal is to lvl up your citizen houses by meeting their needs... a new house lvl means new goods to produce.

producing a good is tedious because you need to manage your power and the eco value.. because an industrialized island will poduce lots of polluant and the soil will acidify and it will lower the rate of production...

theres 2 main races will both a different needs and goods and a different approach to the game.... one is the spiritual entity of greenpeace and the other is japan with all the technology and the pollution

theres also a 3rd race called the techs with a new good tree and a whole different purpuse.. at a high lvl you can research new buildings or items that can affect an island or a ship

on a continuous map you CAN go out and build all 3 race buildings ( like in starcraft 1 if you were the protoss and got a dark archon and mind controlled a drone or a suv )

this game is so big ... theres dozens of feature... like the vote for a senate ( like i said theres 3 races and 1 of them gets elected at the world concil) feature that affects directly how the game runs because each senators give you ''buffs'' you can activate

if you arent sold when i said this game was civilization with more ressources management and a faster pace...nothing can and you are dead inside

reviewText:
This is one of a few games that I see myself coming back to for years. I had two favorite games when I was a kid. One was Total Annihilation -- I particularly loved the navies and building my ports. The second was Simcity 2000. Creating a well-functioning system was satisfying to me. Even moreso when I could see it destroyed.

This is more or less what Anno offers. Anno lets you build a vibrantly complex system of factories, farms, and cities. They depend on you to improve their lives and when you find the balance to do so, it's very rewarding. Combat is secondary to the logistics and economics that are core to the game, but the naval combat is satisfying without being so complex and fast-paced that you cannot attend to the rest of your island empire. It's close to where it needs to be, but there's room for improvement, particularly when it comes time to actually conquer an island or quickly remove an enemy's production capacity. You can also fall victim to disasters: underwater earthquakes that bring tsunamis, massive tornados that will run across your islands like a laser from the sky, nuclear meltdowns and nuclear missiles that will send your people screaming for shelters.

This is also one of the most polished games I've played. There is an incredible amount of visual and audio detail everywhere in the game. Each tiny house has inhabitants. Every street has pedestrians -- pregnant ladies, playing children, hovering trucks. Panning across the oceans you're likely to see a pod of whales or, when you go underwater, a school of fish chased by a shark, with divers exploring in the background. It really makes the game feel alive.

The campaign is okay and the scenarios are worthwhile, but the meat of this game is in the sandbox. It also has a well-designed persistent system that lets you carry items and resources in your mobile headquarters from map to map, ensuring that you only ever have to start from scratch if you really want to and offering room for you to customize bonuses your empire receives so that you can put effort into certain strategies.

reviewText:
back when SETTLERS was a thing age of empire was eating the market... building + management of the buildings and not the units was confusing for all the AOE players...then anno came after... and it all changed...anno is a game where you gotta think 10 game hours before you do anything... take off your age of empire spectacles and enter a game were you NEED to manage over 50 ressources ... at the same time... youll need to produce spices ( if your island has that ressource unlocked ..because each island on the map has different ''seeds'' that limits what you can exploit off that island)  and meat to make hamburgers for your tycoons and satisfy 1 need out of the 7 they suggest... 1 need can be 3 goods to manage... and theres combat too on top of that...because theres so much into building a warship ..you will need to use it wisely because loosing it can hurt you big time.

your main goal is to lvl up your citizen houses by meeting their needs... a new house lvl means new goods to produce.

producing a good is tedious because you need to manage your power and the eco value.. because an industrialized island will poduce lots of polluant and the soil will acidify and it will lower the rate of production...

theres 2 main races will both a different needs and goods and a different approach to the game.... one is the spiritual entity of greenpeace and the other is japan with all the technology and the pollution

theres also a 3rd race called the techs with a new good tree and a whole different purpuse.. at a high lvl you can research new buildings or items that can affect an island or a ship

on a continuous map you CAN go out and build all 3 race buildings ( like in starcraft 1 if you were the protoss and got a dark archon and mind controlled a drone or a suv )

this game is so big ... theres dozens of feature... like the vote for a senate ( like i said theres 3 races and 1 of them gets elected at the world concil) feature that affects directly how the game runs because each senators give you ''buffs'' you can activate

if you arent sold when i said this game was civilization with more ressources management and a faster pace...nothing can and you are dead inside

reviewText:
I'm already sorry I bought this game and I didn't even play a single minute.

Here's what happens if you buy and install the game on Steam:
1. Steam downloads the game.
2. You start the game using Steam.
(Note: This is where you would normally start playing the game)
3. The Anno2070 launcher opens up, downloading stuff (again).
4. You are asked to register your CD key.
5. Ubisoft's uplay client starts up.
6. YOU HAVE TO CREATE A UPLAY ACCOUNT TO PLAY THIS GAME. THERE IS NO WAY AROUND THIS.
7. uplay starts downloading stuff (again²)
8. An installer pops up, installing the game (wtf?)
9. You start the game using uplay.
10. The Anno2070 launcher pops up DOWNLOADING STUFF FOR THE FOURTH TIME.
11. The game launches. (Yay!)
12. The game realizes I bought the complete edition, closes and puts me back to the Anno2070 launcher. The launcher DOWNLOADS STUFF FOR THE FIFTH TIME.
13. The game launches again. I guess I can play. On the plus side: The game prompts me with a survey asking me how I like the experience. Ha ha.

I'm ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and I will not recommend this game even if the gameplay itself would be the greatest revelation of my life. I'm using Steam. Not Origin, not uplay, not you-name-it. I want the game and DLCs downloaded in as few steps as possible.

Valve, I am deeply disappointed that this game is even for sale here. Other games were disqualified for much less, so please slap Ubisoft for this crap.

reviewText:
I have played this game extensively as you can see by my hours played. The Anno series is unique and unlike other city building games. Anno is all about micro managing and making sure your islands have the correct resources while balancing production buildings. Once your citizens are satisified, they can level up into a more prestigous catergory which will require more needs to satisfy the upper class.

The game has awesome graphics, its very pleasing to the eyes.

The DRM used to be a lot worse than what it currently is. Don't let that hold you back from getting this game, its well worth the price. I paid full price for it but grabbed the DLC when it was on sale. The Deep Ocean DLC is worth if once you understand the mechanics of Anno.

I also must note that the game has quite the multi player options. I found it very confusing and never used it, just always played Campaign.

Some important campaign tips: Google good map seed numbers to get good maps that are very big and have lots of mines / rivers / resources / etc. Discover and inhabit as many islands as possible right away. If not, the AI will get it develop it to kick your ♥♥♥ at war. Keto is ♥♥♥♥♥. Hector is annoying but easy to beat as a beginner. Always check your productions lines are working correctly and you don't have huge shortages or surplases. Trading Carbon/Kerosene is the fastest and easiest way to get money fast.

Hope this helps!
voteText: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
First off.... Uplay.
I know, I know, it's a pain in the ♥♥♥, but it's mostly because Steam doesn't bother to update it (with good reason). The updates made by the launcher itself dont work, which means that you just have to download uplay off of Ubisoft. A 3 minute effort for hours of fun with a really nice game.

Dont listen to the negative reviews my friends, please, Uplay isn't that much of a hassle, and definitely shouldn't hinder your decision to buy.

Anno Anno Anno.

I loved the game. It's just hilariously fun to build up your island as a tycoon or tech and then decide you want to nuke everyone else. Loved those aspects of it. City building is fun and difficult, ensuring an interesting experience, and campaign seems quite entertaining too. The lore, which I have not really gone into much lately, is interesting on the surface, and I especially like the conflict between Tech, Tycoon, and Eco.

Combat is interesting, with each faction sporting strengths and weaknesses, and I LOVE the whole submarine side of it, really recommend the DLC and all.
Diplomacy is OK, but I've only scratched the surface and all, since I'm currently sanctioned by, let's check, every single faction on the map, because of my avid use of nuclear warheads. The islands I conquer are currently glass, but I think that I can monopolize on the cathedral building business.

10/10 Would play again

reviewText:
Anno 2070 is a game which nearly deserves its own genre. A mixture of Total Annhiliation-style warfare and epic scale, with the micromanagement of Sim City, and the trading aspects of an empire management sim.

It does so many things right, that it will just suck out your free time, like a black hole.

The Tycoons are the remainder of the present-world high-industrial, short-term, high-profit, fast-building race; which have significant advantages in the early game as well as military, but struggle in the late game.

The Ecos are a future-gazing civilization which try to maintain and raise their ecobalance" (the general health of an inhabited island). They are more difficult to learn
date: but more rewarded overall as they have beautiful architecture
recommended: and their late-game resource demands are significantly less difficult to micro-manage than the Tycoons. They do suffer from certain technology lacks- namely the Tycoon's nuclear reactors
hoursPlayed: and battleships.\n\nThe Techs and other races are "spoilers"
voteText: so I'll let you discover their benefits and drawbacks on your own.\n\nOverall

reviewText:
Anno 2070 is my introduction to the series, I have not played any of the others.

The Premise of Anno is simple, the world has flooded, you take the lead of one of two ideals of how things should work (Eco, or Tycoon) and you build up the world from there.  A third, science like organization unlocks later regardless.

But Anno is an awesome title, the game play is city building/god game, that rellys much more on trade and management of trades, that isn't really found in most games.  You need to establish trade routes to ferry supplys from one island to another, to unlock more trees and get the full extent of everything you need.

The ARK allows you to manipulate the world further to your liking.

I highly recomend this title.

reviewText:
This is one of the best strategy games I've ever played. It's possible to play a relaxing game where you can build multiple cities and balance your production chains or an intense game competing with other players to gain control of valuable resources across multiple islands.

If you've played any of the Caesar or older Anno games then this game should be easy to pick and play however for newer players they'll be a bit of a learning curve but once you figure out how to start controlling resources without everything going to hell in a hand basket you'll be able to enjoy hour upon hour of city building fun.

I should probably also mention the DRM:
TAGES and UPlay are their usual PITA so please take that into consideration before purchasing this game but as long as you're not swapping GPUs every five minutes it shouldn't be an issue.

reviewText:
I've yet to play the game as of yet. But I thought that it was imperative to explain to all those who have had uPlay crash during game start up (like I did).

First time I ran the game, I was surprised with the length of setup. Then when uPlay finally loaded it crashed. So I ran it again, low and behold crash!

Being the determined IT Tech that I am, I browsed to the default UBISoft install folder that uPlay gets installed (much to my dislike it is in C:\Program Files but what ever).

Right click 'Run as Administrator', no crash!

So, in order to fix the issue, uPlay just needs to be elevated into Administrator mode. Most software does this automatically, in this case you can just edit the properties of the uPlay exe to run as administrator every time.

reviewText:
Interesting and pretty at first glance, this game is suffering from 2 fatal flaws for me:

1)-Interface is not intuitive at all and causes way too much wandering around to figure out what to do and how to do it. Ultimate turn off for newcomers.

2)-Anno 2070 campaign is also utterly bugged, I encountered at least a script error per campaign mission, forcing to retry any given mission from scratch in order to find workarounds to complete objectives.

Anno 2070 was certainly a good idea, to this day, it still has gorgeous visual and enthralling ambiance, but unfortunately it has been spoiled by poor polishing and  bug testing.

reviewText:
Anno 2070 is probably the most aesthetically pleasing RTS games I've EVER played. I just love how this game looks. Kinda makes me think of, like, a combination of The Fifth Element and the Star Wars prequels in how cities turn up looking late-game.

This game is ♥♥♥♥ing rad if you like building pretty things. You like pretty Sci-fi buildings? We got it. You like bustling Star Wars cities with ships flyin' everywhere? We got it. You want some dope-♥♥♥ underwater science cities? Well... that's DLC, but we got it. Personally I like Anno 1404 over 2070, but 2070 is just SO graphically pleasing that I can't turn away from it. 8/10, good game, but ♥♥♥♥ you, Ubisoft.

reviewText:
Interesting and pretty at first glance, this game is suffering from 2 fatal flaws for me:

1)-Interface is not intuitive at all and causes way too much wandering around to figure out what to do and how to do it. Ultimate turn off for newcomers.

2)-Anno 2070 campaign is also utterly bugged, I encountered at least a script error per campaign mission, forcing to retry any given mission from scratch in order to find workarounds to complete objectives.

Anno 2070 was certainly a good idea, to this day, it still has gorgeous visual and enthralling ambiance, but unfortunately it has been spoiled by poor polishing and  bug testing.

reviewText:
After playing for a couple of hours, the gameplay is still shallow, boring and repetetive.

Go here to pick up supplies, and bring them here. Build houses. Pick up some more resources from here. Make this building. More houses. Pick up more supplies. Repeat. I feel like I've been playing the tutorial for a couple hours now.

Hey, maybe the game kicks ♥♥♥ once you actually get past this introduction, but I just don't have the patience for that when there are over 100 other PC games I own that I could be playing.

reviewText:
I'm going to start this review off by saying that I actually do recommend this game quite highly, but only to certain people. If you are a casual gamer, turn around now. This game requires so much strategy, planning, and some luck in map generation that trying to play it as you go can and likely will screw you over later in your game.

Pros:
--Great fun to customize your city and build your civilization. Seriously, it gets so exciting and I really don't even know why.
--Sense of accomplishment when you look at your self-sufficient society at the end of a game.

Cons:
--Watching your resources to figure out where your production error stems from is a pain in the ♥♥♥. Fixing it can be even more so.
--This game does not prepare you for itself in any way, shape, or form. I had to watch about three hours of Let's Play" videos before I was prepared for endgame. If not daunted by this review
date: look up the Anno 2070 Beginner's Guide by NsN on youtube. Each of the videos is ~an hour
recommended: but they're funny so it's not a hard watch."

reviewText:
This game is quite good, but it is simply dwarfed by all three of it's immediate pre-decessors and even by the first game in the series ANNO 1602 when it comes to fun and playability.  ANNO 2070 somehow took everything that ANNO 1503 (The worst in the series) did wrong and selectively included most of the enjoyment killing mistakes.
Anno 1440 with the Venice add-on and ANNO 1701 are certainly the best in the series as far as enjoyment and playability are concered.
There is a fine line between too much and too little complexity or micro management.  Too simple and it is boring, too complex and it becomes too laborious.
The whole ecologist vs industrialist thing made good valid social statement (and raises climate change awareness), but did absolutely nothing in the way of making the game fun to play.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Extremely addictive and with beautiful visuals, Anno 2070 is close to GOTY for me. The gameplay is easy to get into but has a profound complexity which slowly unfolds in regular play as your city branches out and your responsibility grows. While single-player free play can entertain you for hours on end as you attempt to foster one or several factions under growing pressure from both the environment and challenger factions, multiplayer can refresh the gameplay and make Anno 2070 feel like a whole new game. The only real drawback for this title is that it's tied to U-Play. Having to download this atrocity and go through it every time you launch the game is an annoyance I can't seem to quell, especially after the hack. [8/10]

reviewText:
After purchasing and installing this game I attempted to log in only to recieve the message Uplay launcher has stopped working".  The error dialog has no further explaination of what action to take and only permits you to close it.  I am left unable to play this game.

EDIT: After three days I got a reply from Ubisoft customer support with instructions on how to re-install the Uplay launcher.  For some reason all of the slash characters in the email were removed (or invisible) which made links and paths to registry entries difficult to decipher.  After some difficulty I got the Uplay launcher working which resolved my issue and allowed the game to run.

For all the good work the game devs did on the actual game it's a shame that the Uplay launcher is as shoddy a piece of work as it is.  I'm not anti-DRM as long as it does NOT get in the way and is PROPERLY MAINTAINED AND SUPPORTED.  Telling customers to hand edit their registry is a VERY BAD idea.  That sort of thing is the entire reason for installers
recommended: and launchers.\n\nBottom line: I enjoy the gameplay but the mediocre customer support and sloppily designed and maintained launcher / DRM has damaged my respect for Ubisoft.  Since I finally got it working I'm happy enough to play the game but even with that if I had the option for a refund I'd take it."

reviewText: I have been waiting for the price to go down on this game and was impressed by the ratings of Anno, so when there was a sale this last week I purchased the Complete Edition.  The UPlay feature is just like everyone describes - hard to get it to work.  You essentially have to modify the security settings on the Uplay folder.  Well I did all that, and was able to play Anno 2070.  Its a good game, complicated, intertwined, good graphics, well thought out, interesting game play.  I wish there was a tutorial, but that is a mnor gripe.   But over the next several days I realized ALL the other games in my Steam library stopped working in some fashion.  Either I could not even get another game to start, or the default key bindings kept getting messed up,  or the other game thought i had not signed into Steam when clearly I was signed in, etc, really weird things on games I have played for months without any problems.  Suddenly I realized what was going on, I uninstalled UPlay (the UBI game loader software) and Anno 2070 and guess what?  Everything else started working...   Guess what company is no longer getting my money?  ANYTHING regarding UBI Soft will be completely disregarded by me.  My advice unless they change something?  Do the same - vote with your money and stay away from this publisher's games, unless they remove their gameloader software!  Its not needed, that what Steam is for!

reviewText:
Things I Liked:
Great Aesthetic - has a distinct style to the UI and the game itself
Interesting Options - class etc. matters
Units are Fun to Test - each one does something different, or has different qualities
War is not Necessary - possible to play peacefully

Things I Didn't:
Uplay - can't be played from Steam directly
Price - is a little overpriced at £15
A Little Old - graphics can look a little dated and the story is a little clichéd

Anno 2070 is a futuristic real time strategy/city builder hybrid game from Ubisoft studios. It was released in November 2011 and is a great game. I've put 7 hour sessions into this game, and I show no signs of stopping. It is a new, futuristic step in the series, and is a strong one.

The basic premise of the game is that the world's sea levels have risen and previous landmasses have become islands, and uninhabitable wastelands have become paradises. It is your mission to repopulate the world from your ark - a kind of sea station.

The ocean is a major focus of this game Much of the expansion and all battle and trading is done by sea. This makes a unit's speed, carrying capacity, armour and damage ever more important. The trading mechanism works really well, being able to set up a different route with each unit is easy and intuitive.

The game is great. It has an interesting style and great development of cities - better in my opinion than the newer Sim Cities. For example, my capital city on my industrial playthrough was growing and I was doing well, and I expanded onto another island. When I went back to my capital, I realised how dense the smog was around the city. It's details like that that really help build immersion and realism.

It's easy to sink hours into a game and not reach the endgame, or even the midgame. If you are a fan of real time strategy games like Age of Empires, then this game is a perfect purchase for you. This award winning mixture of diplomacy, war and construction is sure to win you over to it.

reviewText:
After six hours of this game, and almost five hours of playing it, I'm simultaneous intrigued and disgusted.  It's an interesting game, but unless something changes, I may never buy from UbiSoft again.

I'll start with the good parts.  Anno 2070 is basically Caesar meets Red Alert, with a clever mix of city-building and war that I've seldom seen elsewhere.  While this is ostensibly a real-time strategy game, the combat seems to take a back seat to the economic development of island settlements.  You'll have to manage raw materials, electricity, pollution levels, population, food and drinks, entertainment, and military.  Fortunately the pace is slow enough that this is actually possible.

There are three playable factions, each with different production chains, and specialties.  The Ecos are stereotypical environmentalists with wind farms and tea planations, the Scientists are exactly as you'd expect, eating artificial food and building nuclear power plants, and the Tycoons are your run-of-the-mill capitalists with smoke-belching coal plants and fast food chains.  I haven't played long enough to really contrast them, but so far it seems to work out nicely.

So all in all, it looks like a great game.  So why am I not recommending it?

The observant among you may have noticed the one-hour discrepancy between how long I've had it and how long I've actually been playing it.  Let me start this explanation with a question:  If you buy a game on Steam and hit the Play" button

reviewText:
UPDATE: I have now discovered that there's no way to view detailed information about the economy. This makes it a matter of trial and error to determine how much of what you need to produce. Which I find very frustrating. While I really enjoyed the time I did play the game, I now find myself wishing I'd spent that $30 on beer instead. I have thus updated my review to not recommend the game. It's a brilliant game that's just poorly executed. However, if you're considering it, I do recommend reading the rest of my review. The straw that broke the camel's back for me may not bother you as much.

Original review is all of the following.

TL;DR: This game is sort of in the gray area between SimCity and Civilization (closer to Banished than SimCity as far as city-builders go, if you've played that). It's a brilliant game, but with very noticeable cons. As gameplay isn't really affected by these issues, I'd describe the experience of playing this game as sort of like seeing a fantastic movie in a crappy theatre with uncomfortable chairs and somebody texting a few rows up. You still really enjoy it, but there are small things that bother you a little bit the whole time.

More details: I have many things I like, or even love, about this game. Many things about it are simply brilliant. However, before getting to those, let me first list the caveats without which I would not recommend it. Some of these may be a dealbreaker for you.

-Uplay is very, very annoying. I consider Steam like the iTunes of gaming, and it's as though one record label was like okay well you can listen to our music through iTunes
date: but only if you also open up our other music player software and first validate that you did indeed buy the music." It doesn't prohibit playing
hoursPlayed: very annoying. It's just an extra step that's both unnecessary and inconvenient. And those extra steps add quite a bit of time between purchasing and actually playing

votesFunny: it makes the learning curve much steeper than it should be
commentsCount: and led to a few exasperated shouting matches with my desktop.\n-The cities seem to lack some things that are fundamental in other city builders. For example

reviewText:
My people don't always tell me to demolish my nuclear powerplant, but when they do, I can't find a ♥♥♥♥ to give.

More detailed review:

Graphics: 10/10 in my opinion. Not much to say, other than that pretty much everything looks beautiful.

Music & sound: The music and sounds are pretty good and fitting but not the best I've heard imo 8/10.

Ressource management and economy system: Tedious in the long run. You have to build ships to transport ressources from island to island e.g. island 2 needs Uranium for nuclear energy but uranium is only available on island 1. Unless you import them, but that is quite expensive. The devs did however add a feature that allows your ships to load / unload themselves at your docks, which really helps a lot and makes transport of ressources more or less autonomous. Still, when you start to have 20+ transport ships, it feels kind of like you have a major weakness should you go into battle with the other players. Like should one of them get destroyed whether by a tornado or an enemy, your entire economy on one island might collapse. I suppose it could be lessened by making every ship carry one ressource each rather than several, but that can become expensive to maintain money-wise.
I don't give it less than 7/10 due to the fact you can make your trade autonomous (almost 100%) and renew your ressources (I'm honestly not sure if it's a good or bad things you can renew otherwise non-renewable ressources in rl such as coal...) but I also don't give it a higher score because...Well like I kind of said, the system gets kind of complex and annoying in the long run.
Anyway, 7/10.

Trade: Pretty much the same as above, you just make your ships autonomously load and unload their cargo at other players / AI's docks. Decent trading system, but I feel it could be better somehow. 7/10.

Warfare: Simple and ♥♥♥♥ imho. What can I say, it's a sim game, not a war game. You do have planes, ships, submarines and some other things I can't remember, but it's not quite a good wargame. 4/10.

Climate / weather events: As you can pretty much guess from the description of the game on its store page, your actions affect the environment around you. If you choose to pollute your islands, it could have dramatic effects on your economy, your islands and the other players islands. Oh and it can also happen at sea, so your ships might get destroyed by a tornado all of a sudden. I can imagine that climate system can lead to war in some multiplayer matches. Your people can also oppose some of your actions such as running a nuclear powerplant, fearing a meltdown. You can with techs reduce it to 0%, but the people doesn't seem to care :S Environmentally wise in this game...Let's just say you don't want to run a Business as usual." policy for long. 9/10.

Research and production: Research is insanely and annoyingly slow. You can speed it up and maybe I'm just doing it wrong
date: but researching new techs as well as producing things in your lab takes HOURS. Literally. Production of ships and other units is decent. It's great once you finish researching though
recommended: techs / items you can use to e.g. reduce pollution generated by your coal powerplants or techs that increase your production is great. You can also create...Items? That makes you able to dig up otherwise exhausted ressources. Awesome but also odd given how coal is non-renewable (in human eyes) in the rl. 5/10 due to the insanely slow research.\n\nMultiplayer: I haven't played it that much
hoursPlayed: but it's one of the few strategy games where I actually like multiplayer and don't prefer single player a lot more than multiplayer. I especially like how there are events and campaigns where players have to work together to complete them
voteText: followed by rewards if they succeed (they usually do) for example: "Defeat this terrorist by destroying his bases in these 3 maps." then players help do that and succeed if they complete the maps enough times (not repetitive though). One more thing I especially like that involve other players is...The voting. In the game you can vote for things which will affect your gameplay. It's been a while since I played the game so I don't remember the names and all
helpfulPercent: but you get to vote e.g. for a representative for the tycoons
votesHelpful: which then will increase your production of certain buildings should they win the elections. Anyway
votesTotal: the multiplayer is pretty much similar to singleplayer
votesFunny: meaning it's not laggy or anything. I love CIV V but I hate the thing about having to wait for your turn more than in singleplayer. Anno 2070 doesn't have a similar problem to that
commentsCount:
which is great. 10/10.


Conclusion: I give this game 8/10. I dislike the way to wage war in this game as well as all the cargo ships you end up building in order to transport ressources around. Oh and the slow research. Buy this game if you like sim and strategy games

reviewText:
**Pro's**
Tons of replay and achevements
Nice graphics
Low system requirements
Challanging to play with tons of micromagament
2 and a half playable factions
**Con's**
Tons of micromanagement, if you dont like that.
Uplay & DRM

**Detailed walkthrough of experience**
The game is beautiful and runs very well on my 9 year old PC with max graphics. Causes a little system lag with other programs but minimizing the game fixes this problem in my experience. Outside of small bugs here and there you will encounter in any game this game runs flawlessly with some of the best pathing AI I have seen. Alot of stuff has to be unlocked though gameplay such as player colors, you start out with 4 or 5 colors and unlock more by playing for specific factions durring missions or free play when you complete achevements or special missions in the name of those factions.

Graphically the world is very alive.... you can see towns foke walking around the streets, cars zipping around, police/fire/ambulances running from their buildings to emergency sites including things like hazmat teams quarenteening a house if an epidemic breaks out or fire coming out of a buildings windows if theirs a fire. The world changes based upon its Eco balance, the higher you get the greener and brighter everything seems, the lower you get the darker and gloomier everything looks. BAsed on gameplay settings the eco balance even has effects on your island, causing things like tornados (negative) or tropical thunder storms (positive).

DLC is so well integrated into the game that you can bairly tell it wasnt a basic function, Im still lost on what some of the DLC is or does cause I bought the game and DLC all at once durring the summer sale. Most of the DLC is cosmetic items, such as fountains and parks that can add varity to how your cities look but is completely optional. Other DLC include technologys you cannot get though base game play such as the Eco Balance building Keeper 1.0, New player/account protrates/colors, a few new units, new missions. The only actual expansion to the game itself how ever is Deep Ocean, It adds a new civilization level to the technology faction, S.A.A.T, as well as new missions, buildings, achevements, technologies, disasters and more. If you buy any DLC Deep ocean is a must.

Modules and technology allow for nearly limitless customization, and micromagament can either be a fun or hair pulling experence. Missions are well made and challange you. Even with 100 hours into the game some missions are even still to hard for me to complete.

All maps are randomly generated based on values you can set in before generating the world. There is even artifacts that can be abled from past civilizations that effect the eco balance positively or negatively to even further add varity and challange to gameplay.

2 and a half factions make this game very replayable, and due to the randomization of every map only more so. Why I say 2 and a half factions is because the 3rd research faction, S.A.A.T, does not have basic construction buildings for things like construction blocks or tools, making it impossible to play on its own. It is a supliment to the other two. Even mixing the basic two factions, Tycoons and Eco Warriors, can have benifits. Spit islands and use mining points for iron and copper and use the Tycoons coal diggers to fuel the smelters to provide Eco Warriors with tools to construct Eco Balance buildings. Thats just a simple example of how using both can come to an advantage.

Continus gameplay is astonishing in this game, unlike most I have seen. You can build a civilization, get some base work done, stock up on some materials, load it all into your arc and leave. Start a new map and use all of that stockpile to quickly build a new civilization and keep going. Technology unlocks from research are account unlocks, meaning if you unlock it its unlocked forever. This does add a bit of a level cap" of sorts to the game but you can always choose to restart by emptying everything
date: including technology upgrades from your arc and starting fresh with no help from previous games if you wish to keep playing continus mode. You can disable continus play all togeather in the game options when you make a map. Research how ever unless you disable it in the game options

reviewText:
Like any decent game, it's fun to play for the first few hours because you are learning/exploring. And this game can provide some time-killing with regards to learning how to build and manage your Oceanic Future theme city.

What kills this game for me beyond the first 20 hours is that the AI has unlimited resources and no bases. So you are either building crap an a game where you can't lose, or you are fighting a tough AI that is sending a stream of unlimited warships until you overwhelm them. It's just so lame. I'm not even sure if killing their units matters as it seems like it just triggers them to generate more.

I do want to say though, the GFX and visuals are amazing and I would have loved to play this game for hundreds of hours, but the single player/AI portion is garbage, and the game is a joke in terms of RTS balance/depth to be taken seriously to play on a multiplayer setting.


Finally, I am concerned that this game may no longer work one day due to the DRM in it. Connecting to the login server (to play a single player game) is starting to take longer and longer. They will probably be forced to release a DRM-free'ing patch one day when the cost of running the DRM and customer support with that becomes too costly. In the meantime, I have geniune concerns of players being locked out from playing the game because their DRM servers aren't working and they don't seem to care that much.

reviewText:
Great game, but as everyone else says, uPlay is garbage.  I played this game for many hours over a year ago, and I just built a new PC and wanted something to play.  All the new games are too expensive at the moment, so I thought I'd go back to Anno since the new release is coming soon I felt the nostalgia.  Boy, I had forgotten just what garbage Ubisoft is.  The fact that this game is getting mixed reviews is solely based on the horrible experience provided by their lousy uPlay system.  If they are going to release a game through steam, they had better be darned sure that it works.

That all said, the game itself is great.  If you can get through installing it - and then consequently repairing it and googling around for answers on how to actually make it run, then it's a nice reward.  Just be prepared for a lot of frustration.  You need to be someone who can hunt down problems and fix them, or else you won't even get to start the game.

So, I'm not actually recommending it since the newer game is coming.  I don't think there is any kind of important back story that you would want to play through before getting the newer game, so it's best to leave this one be.  Hopefully the install and configuration will be worked out in the new game and people can get back to reviewing the actual game and not the terrible company that is producing it.

reviewText:
I've never played any of the other Anno games, and although I've only spent a little time in this game so far, I'm convince it's excellent. I've only really encountered the city building experience so far, aside from some minor combat during missions. I definitely think this game is worth checking in to.

PROS:

- Looks great.

- Very deep. Lots of things to keep you busy forever, really.

- Keeps you busy. We all know how tedious city building games can get at times.

- Lots of stuff to unlock.

- Satisfying. When everything balances out well, it just feels good.

CONS:

- Uplay. (I haven't had issues with it, I just dislike the service. Opposed to DRM.)

- Steep-ish learning curve.

This review really doesn't do the game justice, as I'm still only scratching the surface. I'd recommend checking out some videos on Youtube, and deciding for yourself.

reviewText:
The game itself is excellent, but it comes packaged with restrictive and burdensome copy protection. The fact that the game comes bundled with Uplay is bad enough, but the version distributed through Steam crashes to desktop when you try to play your game. I had to uninstall the packaged version of Uplay, install the version distributed by Ubisoft, and completely restart my computer to get it to work.

In summary, it took me 2 hours and as many full restarts of my computer just to get to the main menu of a game I paid for with my own money.

The game is a fairly good city builder, but please get your fix for the genre somewhere else. We don't want to encourage developers who feel that it is okay to treat customers this way.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This game requires a secondary installation of Ubisofts own version of Steam, known as UPlay. Steam will make you install this game, then upon installation of UPlay you will be forced to install the game yet again. IF your steam games are stored on a seperate harddrive, wherever UPlay installs the games will be installed there; so be sure to install UPlay on the same harddrive as your steam games.\n\nAlso, be ware, UPlay will not allow you to play the game unless it has a solid connection to Ubisofts servers. IT does not allow offline mode.

reviewText:
Just purchased and installed it.  When i try to play it though ... It keeps crashing on the UPLAY login screen.  Windows 10 Pro, i5 3570K, 16GB, Nvidia 960 GTX (latest driver), latest windows updates, ...this is seriously lame.

EDIT: Was able to get to play it finally by uninstalling UPLAY and then reinstalling UPLAY.  Then activating the game through UPLAY.  It will NOT launch through steam at all, LIKE, AT ALL.  I have to launch UPLAY first and then launch the game directly through that application.

Also, It randomly crashes on launch and when closing the game.  My machine is a month out of being a fresh windows 7/windows 10 upgrade install.  What an incredible pain in the ♥♥♥.

I will never buy another game with DRM this craptastic again.  Seriously UBISOFT, why would you do this to people?

People, save yourself the $$ ... Good game or not, this kind of DRM scheme a serious pain in the ♥♥♥.  We shouldn't reward companies like this with our $$.  There are plenty of other developers out there, with amazing games, that don't punish their customers in this way.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Bought it, then stared at the DRM login ♥♥♥♥, tried to log in, and it didnt work. Tried 1 year later, still didnt work.

Autenticating it through Steam should be enough, making me login twice is ♥♥♥♥ed in the head, unless its a MMO or some ♥♥♥♥(which this isnt).

Recently played it though, and its... not as good as the previous ones unfortunately.

If I had to score it without the DRM i'd give it 6/10, but the DRM pulls it down to a easy 2/10.
